commit_message:
Install default storage class for Cinder

Volumes cannot be automatically created if there is no StorageClass
as Kubernetes will endlessly try to create them with no 'direction'
on where to add them.

This will install a StorageClass by default in all clusters so that
it can create volumes inside Cinder without any additional work.

Closes-Bug: #1714356
Change-Id: I226ec1d3ce66ad758585245e10408d4b39b84ad7

commit_message:
Handling failure in getting etcd discovery url

Before creating a cluster we are checking whether we are able to
access `https://discovery.etcd.io` or not. If we are able to access
it we are creating the cluster, if not we are raising exception.

Change-Id: I3bbd48f14c5bf7cbd5788d1efa2ac53c7e97ea75
Closes-Bug: #1704329

I think there is a mix of two attributes here.
1. registry_enabled
|-- this create a chaching registry on swift 
2. insecure_registry
|-- uses a custom registry_url to put in docker config

https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/registryv2-in-master
https://blueprints.launchpad.net/magnum/+spec/support-insecure-registry

I think you need only 2'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2017-02-08 10:11:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

commit_message:
[suse] Add custom docker REGISTRY_URL option

Adds that uses a custom registry_url to put in docker config which
allows to have private docker registry.

Partial-bug: #1622949
Change-Id: I2ceb6c0adfbcdc37bac50402a6ca3dbdd4a11b47

commit_message:
Create hidden stacks for clusters

At the moment, the user could directly interact with the stacks
which can cause some problems or confusion from the user side
of things.

This patch hides the stack from the user which will mean that
they will no longer be seeing stacks which they should not be
managing.

Change-Id: Ic8fd31732e3041d77fdb070cee46bbcc61a4a4db

Build succeeded.

- nova http://cloudbase-ci.com/nova/638207/11 : SUCCESS in 2h 15m 55s'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-04-08 16:52:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

> If racing between neutron's reality and the cache is not a concern
 > here, is there a reason to not always use a cache, and set the dict
 > on the first call to list_ports, instead of pre-warming it when
 > unlimited is set?
 > 
 > That is: only make the call to list_ports if the cache is empty at
 > the time of use, and cache the results for the next time. If there
 > is no next time, no harm done, if there is, win.

I don't have a solid answer for this. I'm guessing here:
If unlimited is not used then the healing is done one batch at a time and after a batch the CLI exits. The batch size defaults to 50 instances. So in a non unlimited case creating a cache might not worth the effort as that cache will contain all ports but it will be dropped after 50 instances. In the other hand if the run in unlimited then the script might benefit from having a cache.

Regarding not pre-warming the cache but creating at the first call. That first call will be the first instance processed as we have to check for each instance if it has a port with resource request. So we can only spare time by not pre-warming the cache if there is 0 instances in the deployment."}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-04-08 16:57:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 12: Patch Set 11 was rebased.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2019-04-08 16:57:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12: Workflow-1

Needs test'}, {'account_id': 23498, 'date': '2019-04-08 19:04:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 12:

Testing completed on the zVM Driver CI system check-nova pipeline and failed.  To recheck only the zVM driver plugins, submit a comment with only  zvm: recheck in the comment.. Contact information: zvmosci@us.ibm.com. For information see https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/ZVMDriver.

subject: Simplify release naming process
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 308, 'name': 'Thierry Carrez', 'email': 'thierry@openstack.org', 'username': 'ttx'}, {'_account_id': 1004, 'name': 'Mohammed Naser', 'email': 'mnaser@vexxhost.com', 'username': 'mnaser'}, {'_account_id': 4257, 'name': 'Zane Bitter', 'email': 'zbitter@redhat.com', 'username': 'zaneb'}, {'_account_id': 5314, 'name': 'Brian Rosmaita', 'email': 'rosmaita.fossdev@gmail.com', 'username': 'brian-rosmaita'}, {'_account_id': 7198, 'name': 'Jay Bryant', 'email': 'jungleboyj@electronicjungle.net', 'username': 'jsbryant'}, {'_account_id': 8099, 'name': 'Graham Hayes', 'email': 'gr@ham.ie', 'username': 'graham'}, {'_account_id': 8556, 'name': 'Ghanshyam', 'display_name': 'Ghanshyam Mann', 'email': 'gmann@ghanshyammann.com', 'username': 'ghanshyam'}, {'_account_id': 10607, 'name': 'Alexandra Settle', 'email': 'a.settle@outlook.com', 'username': 'asettle'}, {'_account_id': 13995, 'name': 'Nate Johnston', 'email': 'nate.johnston@redhat.com', 'username': 'natejohnston'}, {'_account_id': 14070, 'name': 'Eric Fried', 'email': 'openstack@fried.cc', 'username': 'efried'}, {'_account_id': 16708, 'name': 'Kendall Nelson', 'display_name': 'Kendall (diablo_rojo)', 'email': 'kennelson11@gmail.com', 'username': 'kjnelson'}, {'_account_id': 17068, 'name': 'Jean-Philippe Evrard', 'email': 'openstack@a.spamming.party', 'username': 'evrardjp'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
messages:
[{'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-19 19:59:18.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-11-19 20:22:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-11-19 22:52:42.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote-1

Nope.   I rewrote my reasoning many times for this but it all boils down to a small group of people shouldn't decide what the name of a community effort is.

That's just not what we're about as a community and frankly I'd be extremely disappointed if this is the path we end up going, being an authority that decides on what the release name is."}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-20 07:34:10.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from tc-release-naming to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-20 07:36:58.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> Nope.   I rewrote my reasoning many times for this but it all boils
 > down to a small group of people shouldn't decide what the name of a
 > community effort is.
 > 
 > That's just not what we're about as a community and frankly I'd be
 > extremely disappointed if this is the path we end up going, being
 > an authority that decides on what the release name is.

Well the thing is, with all the propositions we got on the table, everyone was unpleased by this. At the summit we discussed it (we had a majority of people around the table for the meeting), and that was what we came up with. Community still proposes names and can lobby for their names to be up to the TC members. Or they can step up and be member of the TC :)"}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-20 12:29:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

@mnaser - sure, it is not an amazing outcome - but nothing else proposed had anything even close to a consensus at the PTG. 

I understand that a small group is less than ideal, but I would rather not burn someone's time on running an election. Is this something the people that elected us really care about, or would they rather we chose this, and focused on things that impact on project velocity or stability?"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:47:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

My -1 shouldn't be blocking, but I want to be on record: I don't like the electorate not being the community."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:50:15.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

FWIW I didn't get the impression that any of the other proposals were stalled on the question of the electorate. I got the impression that everyone who cared at all cared strongly that the electorate be the whole community. It was just the generation of names we couldn't agree on."}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-11-20 18:39:32.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

This is consistent with what we discussed at the PTG.'}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-11-21 10:44:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Rollcall-Vote+1

(2 comments)

If the name was currently really decided by "the community" I'd probably agree with Eric and Mohammed... but that ship has sailed a long time ago and in the current system it is an open CIVS poll, which means that anyone can vote (and as many times as they want). The result is not much more representative of "the community" than asking the body specifically elected to represent the community to rank options.

The benefits of this system are:

- with less constraints in acceptable names, the community should be more involved in *proposing* names, so this remains a community game. A more enjoyable game than, say, vote to rank names of cities of more than 100,000 inhabitants

- it allows to have a wide set of proposals, without having to reduce the list to a small set to accommodate a large group of people voting

- vote is easier to organize, and the result is arguably as representative of "the community" than the previous system

- discussion on cultural/sensitive issues can happen at the TC level, so all voters can be assumed to be aware of them'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:50:13.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2.'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:51:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:51:47.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from tc-release-naming to formal-vote'}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-11-21 16:09:17.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 7198, 'date': '2019-11-21 16:42:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

Looks good.'}, {'account_id': 13995, 'date': '2019-11-21 21:03:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-21 21:57:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

Update acked, ttx's reasoning acked, passive-aggressively abstaining."}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-11-22 12:06:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)

(1 comment)

If I am wrong on the disparity (see inline), I will change my vote to a +1. It matches what we talked about at the PVG, PTG and overall has my +1.'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-11-25 15:31:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-11-26 14:17:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 8556, 'date': '2019-12-03 15:53:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote-1

Like in PTG, I still disagree with the proposal of changing the voters from the community to TC-only. 

The voting system was not a problem so I am confused about what exactly we are solving by changing it. The problem was just choosing the names which I think should be solved by changing the 'Release Name Criteria' section only. TC should solve the pre-work/criteria to choose the name list and let the community select the final name."}, {'account_id': 308, 'date': '2019-12-05 10:39:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 4257, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:16:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3:

> The voting system was not a problem

You're ignoring the fact that the electorate was not the OpenStack community (however you define it), but the Internet at large, and that anyone could vote as many times as they could find IP addresses, unless of course they were behind the same NAT as their colleague who had already voted, in which case they couldn't vote at all.

> The problem was just choosing the names

The problem was that the TC owns the release name and is accountable for making sure that neither the chosen name nor the process causes any geopolitical incidents, and therefore must exercise editorial control at some point, but this was not documented. Previously we did that at the name selection stage and it caused widespread complaints. This proposal flips things around so that the TC editorialises at the voting stage instead. We are not constrained to keep some part of the previous solution sacrosanct; we can solve it wherever in the process produces the best outcome.

People are going to be unhappy with literally any solution to the problem, because many of them had come to believe that the Internet was entitled to make Its decision without any editorial component entering into it. This proposal at least has the virtue of not perpetuating that impression. It's almost too much to dream, but perhaps someday TC members will be able to spend their time doing something useful for OpenStack instead of burning their biggest single time commitment on rehashing procedures for choosing the release name."}, {'account_id': 8099, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:51:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 16708, 'date': '2019-12-09 18:52:09.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1 -Code-Review

All cleared up on phrasing now. Looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 10607, 'date': '2019-12-10 15:52:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Rollcall-Vote+1'}, {'account_id': 17068, 'date': '2019-12-11 08:50:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 3: Workflow+1

As the majority of the TC is for this, let's continue in that direction. Let's put this to bed."}]

commit_message:
Simplify release naming process

Names can (and should) be proposed by the community, and the TC will then
rank them, and the process can continue as before.

This patch also removes the requirement to tie the name to a geographic
location for events that may or may not happen in line with the cycles.

Change-Id: Ie7d26312628bb7d26bcba39ec24213b3a08b6793
Signed-off-by: Graham Hayes <gr@ham.ie>

commit_message:
Add ansible-collections-openstack to ansible-sig

The ansible community is devolving core modules into "collections"
which can be managed in their own git repos, and do not have to be
located on github.

The ansible-sig has been formed to manage all-things Ansible inside
the OpenStack community so moving the modules into a collection
on OpenDev maintained by the ansible-sig is a good-next-step.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/684738
Change-Id: I0e0e67ef5c76241e78e772f6a8dc8438f5379729
Signed-off-by: Mohammed Naser <mnaser@vexxhost.com>

commit_message:
Do not fail ARQ binding for specific Nova notification errors.

Cyborg's ARQ binding notification may be lost if Nova has not yet
associated the instance with a host. In that case, Nova returns
HTTP 207 with a per-event failure code of 422. Cyborg should not
fail the ARQ binding in that case.

See:
https://review.opendev.org/#/c/631244/46/nova/compute/manager.py@2627.

Change-Id: I6f9f7bd7fd25c566f051c31622003da7069ba541

subject: Cleanup session object
messages:
[{'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-08-01 20:41:29.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 597, 'date': '2019-12-05 21:27:46.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

Abishkek, are you okay with this? We're having a little bit of a controversy in Swift over the sister review. What's the Glance core's perspective?

https://review.opendev.org/674320"}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-12-06 06:07:07.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

IMO it is not guaranteed that this __del__ method will be called all the time, but this could be the easiest way to close the session. Lets see what other cores suggests on this.'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-09 20:08:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

Thanks for looking into this Alex,

Couple of quiestions, one technical nit inline, the other as following.

If we kill the session every time we get rid of the client, why should we allow passing the session in at the first place? I do agree that leaving orphaned sessions around is not great practise (and not sure why that happens in the first place and is not taken care of by garbage collection, is this perhaps problem in requests not cleaning system resources correctly?).

If I understand this patch correctly anyone who passes their session to the client after this patch will send it to suicide mission as that session will be closed after the client gets cleaned meaning that the session cannot be used again.

Wouldn't it make sense to rather keep track if this is session that was created during the client initialization or even better look into not using session if one is not passed to the client?

My bigger concern is that the __del__ method will be called most of the time rather than Abhisheks concern that it might not be called every time."}, {'account_id': 14985, 'date': '2019-12-09 20:30:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)

So unlike the other clients, glanceclient doesn't accept a session.
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient/src/branch/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L157-L184  If it did then we could reuse sessions and control this externally. The problem is that it doesn't so we get a warning printed every time we consume glanceclient. swiftclient and keystoneauth1 also suffered from this problem but patches have merged to address those.

It always creates a session. 


Other clients: 

https://opendev.org/openstack/python-novaclient/src/branch/master/novaclient/client.py#L89-L154
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-cinderclient/src/branch/master/cinderclient/client.py#L689-L740
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-neutronclient/src/branch/master/neutronclient/client.py#L382-L435
https://opendev.org/openstack/python-barbicanclient/src/branch/master/barbicanclient/client.py#L122-L181


The issue here is just to attempt to close the session semi-cleanly rather than leaving it open at the end and forcefully killing things off. Right now the session isn't closed properly and there doesn't really appear to be any other way here to try and do it at the end of the glance client lifecycle. Yes __del__ may not be called because of other references, but I would bet that's not the regular consumption of these clients."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-10 11:40:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

> (1 comment)
 > 
 > So unlike the other clients, glanceclient doesn't accept a session.
 > https://opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient/src/branch/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L157-L184
 >  If it did then we could reuse sessions and control this
 > externally. The problem is that it doesn't so we get a warning
 > printed every time we consume glanceclient. swiftclient and
 > keystoneauth1 also suffered from this problem but patches have
 > merged to address those.

It does, you just get SessionClient instance instead, so I assume you're initializing HTTPClient direcftly https://opendev.org/openstack/python-glanceclient/src/branch/master/glanceclient/common/http.py#L381-L388

Honestly didn't remember myself that it was implemented this way in python-glanceclient.

Which makes absolutely sense, we should be doing this in the HTTPClient which will always have the session created by itself."}, {'account_id': 9303, 'date': '2019-12-11 06:35:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you Alex!!'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-01 20:41:29.000000000', 'message': "Cleanup session object

If a session object is not provided to the get_http_client function (as
is done via osc), the glance client uses it's own HTTPClient class. This
class creates a session but does not properly close it when it is done.
This can lead to resource warnings about unclosed sockets. This change
adds a __del__() to the HTTPClient class to close out the session
correctly.

Change-Id: Idccff338fa84c46ca0e429bb533a2a5217205eef
Closes-Bug: #1838694
"}]
commit_message:
Cleanup session object

If a session object is not provided to the get_http_client function (as
is done via osc), the glance client uses it's own HTTPClient class. This
class creates a session but does not properly close it when it is done.
This can lead to resource warnings about unclosed sockets. This change
adds a __del__() to the HTTPClient class to close out the session
correctly.

Change-Id: Idccff338fa84c46ca0e429bb533a2a5217205eef
Closes-Bug: #1838694

commit_message:
Keep Neutron port's binding profile when unbinding in case of SmartNIC port

Neutron OVS agent needs SmartNIC representor name in order to remove it
from OVS db.
In case of SmartNIC port, it must have binding profile object that
containes `port_id` attribute in it's local_link_information.

Change-Id: I17e2d7ecebdb961e3e0ba0bcfa249567ebb1835f
Closes-Bug: #1855260

commit_message:
Copy all_nodes.json instead of rendering template

Rendering all_nodes.json on each node is proving to be a performance
bottleneck. Given that it is the same data on each node and it has
already been rendered as group_vars/overcloud.json on the control node
(undercloud), it can just be copied to each node.

commit_message:
Move localhost_address to net_ip_map hieradata

all_nodes is meant to be for hieradata that is the same across all
nodes, while localhost_address could possibly be node specific. This
change moves it from all_nodes to net_ip_map.

This will allow rendering the all_nodes template once and then just
copying it into place, which will be a significant performance
improvement.

Change-Id: Ie3b5f242bc2afce9d395e29db498b3516f8bcc3c

[{'created': '2019-12-04 15:06:30.000000000', 'message': 'New Parameter NovaCronArchiveDeleteAllCells and NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsAge

Introduces two new parameters to configure the archive deleted
instances cron job.
1) NovaCronArchiveDeleteAllCells
To make sure deleted instances get archived also from the cell0
in a single cell deployment and also in additional cell databases
in case of a multi cell deployment.

2) NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsAge
--before is required to prevent the orphaning of libvirt guests
if/when nova-compute is down when a db archive cron job fires.

This change also modifies
1) the default from 100 to 1000 for NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsMaxRows
to match the default from the nova-manage command instead the default
of 100 from the puppet-nova parameter.

2) changes the default for NovaCronPurgeShadowTablesAllCells from
false to true also the nova-manage db purge command needs to run
for all cells instead of only the default cell.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/696900

commit_message:
New Parameter NovaCronArchiveDeleteAllCells and NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsAge

Introduces two new parameters to configure the archive deleted
instances cron job.
1) NovaCronArchiveDeleteAllCells
To make sure deleted instances get archived also from the cell0
in a single cell deployment and also in additional cell databases
in case of a multi cell deployment.

2) NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsAge
--before is required to prevent the orphaning of libvirt guests
if/when nova-compute is down when a db archive cron job fires.

This change also modifies
1) the default from 100 to 1000 for NovaCronArchiveDeleteRowsMaxRows
to match the default from the nova-manage command instead the default
of 100 from the puppet-nova parameter.

2) changes the default for NovaCronPurgeShadowTablesAllCells from
false to true also the nova-manage db purge command needs to run
for all cells instead of only the default cell.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/696900
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/697299

Change-Id: I91cb1e16f65b23117235d4eac76f03748b47e926

commit_message:
compute: Use long_rpc_timeout in reserve_block_device_name

Given the instance.uuid lock taken on the remote compute, calls to
reserve_block_device_name can take a large amount of time to complete
when attaching multiple volumes. To help avoid timeouts during such
attempts this change switches to using the long_rpc_timeout for the
overall timeout for each call.

Conflicts:
        nova/conf/rpc.py

NOTE(lyarwood): Conflict due to
If32bca070185937ef83f689b7163d965a89ec10a not being present in
stable/stein.

Related-Bug: #1844296
Change-Id: I17e0e45117a3312c11d6c7f2762dd416b6067979
(cherry picked from commit 648c05f7bee025087c2f9d8e2f9cda6e2c13e13f)
(cherry picked from commit f9a1bc71050b41753259b96998a2a4b4dc8ecd79)

commit_message:
compute: Use long_rpc_timeout in reserve_block_device_name

Given the instance.uuid lock taken on the remote compute, calls to
reserve_block_device_name can take a large amount of time to complete
when attaching multiple volumes. To help avoid timeouts during such
attempts this change switches to using the long_rpc_timeout for the
overall timeout for each call.

Related-Bug: #1844296
Change-Id: I17e0e45117a3312c11d6c7f2762dd416b6067979
(cherry picked from commit 648c05f7bee025087c2f9d8e2f9cda6e2c13e13f)
(cherry picked from commit f9a1bc71050b41753259b96998a2a4b4dc8ecd79)
(cherry picked from commit e858ab3bbe79bde32cce4bc661c0c4edc04b51d3)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-27 16:44:41.000000000', 'message': 'Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
'}, {'created': '2019-12-09 19:36:16.000000000', 'message': 'Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
(cherry picked from commit 5e858d0cbd672639318543201e251ed00324a9c2)
(cherry picked from commit 9f9f8d330a50aec188e55ab8ae921db710e6cc83)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
(cherry picked from commit 5e858d0cbd672639318543201e251ed00324a9c2)
(cherry picked from commit 9f9f8d330a50aec188e55ab8ae921db710e6cc83)

[{'created': '2019-08-16 15:06:18.000000000', 'message': 'Docs: Make robust with using real links

Our tools noticed that keystone links to
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/identity-domain-specific-config.html
which does not exist anymore.

The page was removed but the link to it was not changed. Replace this
and similar links with internal links that will work even if files are
moved - and can be verified, thus sphinx will error in case of broken
targets.

These changes include a few other fixes for broken keystone links, e.g.
to renamed anchors.

For the include files in admin/configuration.rst and
admin/federation/configure_federation.rst: Rename them to *inc.
The files were
published twice (as separate files and on this page) and thus
referencing failed. Renaming avoids this.

Also, put doctree outside of html tree so that it does not get
published.

Change-Id: I3d07637b0046cc88a66bcb51a0a4fe7c146c1549

commit_message:
Docs: Make robust with using real links

This backport squashes f10f95b and the correction 4ed39d5.

Our tools noticed that keystone links to
https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/latest/admin/identity-domain-specific-config.html
which does not exist anymore.

The page was removed but the link to it was not changed. Replace this
and similar links with internal links that will work even if files are
moved - and can be verified, thus sphinx will error in case of broken
targets.

These changes include a few other fixes for broken keystone links, e.g.
to renamed anchors.

For the include files in admin/configuration.rst and
admin/federation/configure_federation.rst: Rename them to *inc.
The files were
published twice (as separate files and on this page) and thus
referencing failed. Renaming avoids this.

Also, put doctree outside of html tree so that it does not get
published.

(cherry picked from commit f10f95b455806ce28b112827a794618957e1f829)

Fix relative links

Fix minor errors introduced in f10f95b4.

(cherry picked from commit 4ed39d530f5589aabd880de7917424cca700650f)

Change-Id: I3d07637b0046cc88a66bcb51a0a4fe7c146c1549

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-28 08:40:06.000000000', 'message': '[Functional tests] Fix SIGHUP handling tests

Tests in networking_sfc.functional.test_server module are testing how
service is handling SIGHUP signal.

Recently this was changed in Oslo.service with [1] and our tests
were failing because they were still expecting that after sending
SIGHUP to the process, stop() and than start() method will be called.

But as our services uses "mutate" as restart method, since [1] such
process don't executes stop() and start() after SIGHUP. It now executes
only reset() method.
Similar change was recently done in Neutron's functional tests in [2].
This patch reflects that change in networking-sfc functional tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/641907/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680001/

Change-Id: I22629c59da983f47ef8b1862afb9a62bdfd78b02
Closes-Bug: #1842659
(cherry picked from commit 0644862c8beedd902a7d739be524699edc9b61d3)
'}]
commit_message:
[Functional tests] Fix SIGHUP handling tests

Tests in networking_sfc.functional.test_server module are testing how
service is handling SIGHUP signal.

Recently this was changed in Oslo.service with [1] and our tests
were failing because they were still expecting that after sending
SIGHUP to the process, stop() and than start() method will be called.

But as our services uses "mutate" as restart method, since [1] such
process don't executes stop() and start() after SIGHUP. It now executes
only reset() method.
Similar change was recently done in Neutron's functional tests in [2].
This patch reflects that change in networking-sfc functional tests.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/641907/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/680001/

Change-Id: I22629c59da983f47ef8b1862afb9a62bdfd78b02
Closes-Bug: #1842659
(cherry picked from commit 0644862c8beedd902a7d739be524699edc9b61d3)

Elasticsearch: Make node selectors more granular

This updates the Elasticsearch chart to make the values keys used
for defining node selectors for the various elasticsearch
components more granular

Change-Id: Ic1ac343b1d6ee48fc7cb456afe4cd9588c4aa13b
Signed-off-by: Steve Wilkerson <sw5822@att.com>

commit_message:
Template custom HAProxy service configuration

Change Id84e3b6e62e544582d6917047534e846e026798d added support for
custom HAProxy service config using a plain copy of files in services.d.

Use a template action instead of a copy so that we can use variables and
iterate over group of hosts.

Change-Id: I1f07785932de4e4540422bd18af95241f05a67bf

commit_message:
Workarounds: remove --reverse from patch options

The --reverse option causes patch to fail even if the diff is
just few lines off. The reverse option to check if patch was
applied is not a good idea with yaml. It's fairly easy to create
reverse patch for patch that wasn't applied.

Change-Id: I4a1459344794f5d602dc1b781d15a591ea2ac135
(cherry picked from commit a4fa67c1f91c655eb97ae634566aad03bd4a00e5)

commit_message:
Fix tox 'bindep' environment

tox.ini is hard-coded to always use the 'test' profile for bindep;
instead, let tox get the profile from the posargs

Closes-bug: #1841836
Change-Id: I24bfb313cf28b20037f5f9aea9417bc8371bfd91

[{'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-07 17:48:32.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 11292, 'date': '2019-12-07 20:49:06.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

I don't see how the move from serialized to parallel is triggering/exacerbate the issue ... shouldn't the lack of a stop always have caused trouble? I'm probably missing something ...

That being said, the change itself looks good to me!"}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2019-12-08 15:09:03.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-08 22:17:25.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> I don't see how the move from serialized to parallel is
 > triggering/exacerbate the issue ... shouldn't the lack of a stop
 > always have caused trouble? I'm probably missing something ...
 > 
 > That being said, the change itself looks good to me!

The old code would literally only handle one request at a time with an open socket. I suspect it was something like a finally block that closed the socket out in the pecan server wsgi server instance. As a result of one request at a time, the code block was previously able to immediately exit once self.serve_api was set to false."}, {'account_id': 11076, 'date': '2019-12-09 03:43:20.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1

Thank you Julia.'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:13:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-09 10:04:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

I think wait() is enough, but you at least need both wait() and stop(): https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.service/src/branch/master/oslo_service/wsgi.py#L229-L243'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-09 10:06:49.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-09 10:49:34.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

Thinking more about it, let's proceed. With the extend to which the standalone job is broken, we cannot afford more revisions easily :(

Note that rescue did pass on the original patch, so dunno.."}, {'account_id': 10239, 'date': '2019-12-09 12:55:28.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck now the mirrors misbehaving..'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-12-09 15:46:54.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I did a local test and I can confirm an issue with the tinycore mirrors at the same point, guess we'll have to wait for a fix"}, {'account_id': 11655, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:54:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-07 17:48:32.000000000', 'message': 'Stop the API so rescue can exit and succeed

The change in frameworks with the API changed the overall execution
behavior from single threaded serialized execution threaded to
multithreaded through eventlet.

But we signaled ourselves to wait for the API to stop, but never
actually stopped the API.

As setting the flag to stop the API is a hard notification that
the API must now exit, there is no reason to wait and block exit,
hence the simple nature of this change.

Now the threads should exit, IPA should exit, and rescue should
ideally work.

Change-Id: I3faf2d169d4edac6a2321f8649bb9ce478885ea1
Story: 2006998
Task: 37768
'}]
commit_message:
Stop the API so rescue can exit and succeed

The change in frameworks with the API changed the overall execution
behavior from single threaded serialized execution threaded to
multithreaded through eventlet.

But we signaled ourselves to wait for the API to stop, but never
actually stopped the API.

As setting the flag to stop the API is a hard notification that
the API must now exit, there is no reason to wait and block exit,
hence the simple nature of this change.

Now the threads should exit, IPA should exit, and rescue should
ideally work.

Change-Id: I3faf2d169d4edac6a2321f8649bb9ce478885ea1
Story: 2006998
Task: 37768

commit_message:
Drop pip-conf-removal task

This task was essential for migration from R->S as we were
migrtating from usage of wheels stored on repo server to
usage of python_venv_build role. This task is not relevant now
and can be dropped. Moreover it makes upgrade script re-run fail
during S->T upgrade when upgrade playbook failed first time before
finishing setup_hosts playbook (creating all required containers).

Change-Id: Ice98040e529f21c7369df45b020b284c959d9c8c
(cherry picked from commit 88bb4d33d99de6810f07f3c60052d1fe49cfa10f)

subject: swift-external: deprecate External*Url
reviewers: [{'_account_id': 3153, 'name': 'Emilien Macchi', 'email': 'emilien@redhat.com', 'username': 'emilienm'}, {'_account_id': 11090, 'name': 'Sergii Golovatiuk', 'email': 'sgolovat@redhat.com', 'username': 'holser'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 20172, 'name': 'Michele Baldessari', 'email': 'michele@acksyn.org', 'username': 'michele'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 23:20:49.000000000', 'message': "swift-external: deprecate External*Url

ExternalPublicUrl (and the 2 others) are too generic to know that they
are for Swift only.
Let's rename them and deprecate the old ones.

This patch does the following:
ExternalPublicUrl, ExternalAdminUrl and ExternalInternalUrl are deprecated.
ExternalSwiftPublicUrl, ExternalSwiftAdminUrl and ExternalSwiftInternalUrl
should now be used.

Change-Id: I4634447762aad20f2c450fe4bb7f0803d13efec2
"}]
commit_message:
swift-external: deprecate External*Url

ExternalPublicUrl (and the 2 others) are too generic to know that they
are for Swift only.
Let's rename them and deprecate the old ones.

This patch does the following:
ExternalPublicUrl, ExternalAdminUrl and ExternalInternalUrl are deprecated.
ExternalSwiftPublicUrl, ExternalSwiftAdminUrl and ExternalSwiftInternalUrl
should now be used.

Change-Id: I4634447762aad20f2c450fe4bb7f0803d13efec2

Set neutron_service_region in group_vars

The other roles wire 'service_region' to the role specific service
region variable. Do the same for neutron.

subject: Metadata agent: fetch ovn-bridge from OVSDB and not from config
messages: [{'account_id': 8655, 'date': '2019-11-25 08:51:25.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 1131, 'date': '2019-11-25 20:36:00.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2019-12-10 15:26:46.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1\n\nBackported some time ago up to rocky'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-25 08:51:25.000000000', 'message': "Metadata agent: fetch ovn-bridge from OVSDB and not from config

Prior to this patch, metadata agent was fetching the OVN bridge
from the settings but this could lead to inconsistencies if the
config is different from the actual OVSDB configuration as
ovn-controller would be using one bridge and Metadata agent
another one.

In order to eliminate these inconsistencies, this patch is
changing the behavior of the agent so that it reads the OVN
bridge from OVSDB as ovn-controller does. Also, when the
agent is restarted, if the bridge has changed, it'll plug all
the VETH pairs to the right bridge and unplug it from the older
one (this is handy for the migration from ML2/OVS where an
intermediate OVS bridge is used temporarily).

The config option is not removed by this patch but ignored to
avoid issues when it doesn't match OVSDB configuration.

 Conflicts:
	networking_ovn/agent/metadata/agent.py
	networking_ovn/tests/functional/test_metadata_agent.py

Change-Id: I33f3509b8e5fe0398a27d35923e46f0409a1935d
Closes-Bug: #1799216
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3e5d9213aa9d59029107ba51d6c0876d6d7d8b2a)
(cherry picked from commit 950a53748c6f423cdb583b87d1e97711e30bebb8)
"}]
commit_message:
Metadata agent: fetch ovn-bridge from OVSDB and not from config

Prior to this patch, metadata agent was fetching the OVN bridge
from the settings but this could lead to inconsistencies if the
config is different from the actual OVSDB configuration as
ovn-controller would be using one bridge and Metadata agent
another one.

In order to eliminate these inconsistencies, this patch is
changing the behavior of the agent so that it reads the OVN
bridge from OVSDB as ovn-controller does. Also, when the
agent is restarted, if the bridge has changed, it'll plug all
the VETH pairs to the right bridge and unplug it from the older
one (this is handy for the migration from ML2/OVS where an
intermediate OVS bridge is used temporarily).

The config option is not removed by this patch but ignored to
avoid issues when it doesn't match OVSDB configuration.

 Conflicts:
	networking_ovn/agent/metadata/agent.py
	networking_ovn/tests/functional/test_metadata_agent.py

Change-Id: I33f3509b8e5fe0398a27d35923e46f0409a1935d
Closes-Bug: #1799216
Signed-off-by: Daniel Alvarez <dalvarez@redhat.com>
(cherry picked from commit 3e5d9213aa9d59029107ba51d6c0876d6d7d8b2a)
(cherry picked from commit 950a53748c6f423cdb583b87d1e97711e30bebb8)

commit_message:
Migrate neutron-vpnaas tests to neutron-tempest-plugin

As discussed in the neutron_ci meeting [1] the QA team would like to
move the tempest tests for the stadium projects from their repos to
repos specific to being tempest plugins.  This is the first part of a
two stage move, by copying over the tempest tests to the
neutron-tempest-plugin repo [2] rather than spawning new repos to be
separate.

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/neutron_ci/2019/neutron_ci.2019-03-12-16.01.log.html#l-94
[2] https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/neutron_stadium_move_to_tempest_plugin_repo

Needed-By: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695834
Change-Id: Icbeaf8fd8543c4cbd9a7dadbe4467d88023c4b47

commit_message:
Force building amphora image

The prebuilt test amphora images we use to speed up testing in the gates
are only built for master. Those should not be used for stable branches
and this commit makes sure we don't do that in stable/train.

Change-Id: I134853344b3130435b1b93b44d39b7f3335267d0

commit_message:
bug: Only query Cinder API if volume size > 0

Only query Cinder API for volume type if volume size is greater than 0.
This is to make sure that Magnum does not have a hard dependency on
Cinder and works without the Cinder API enlisted as an endpoint.

This regression was introduced in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/621734/
where boot from volume support was introduced. See
https://storyboard.openstack.org/#!/story/2005386#comment-147555 for
more details of the error.

Story: 2005386
Task: 37565

(cherry picked from commit 26a171f951cb40809d378af82433dbe28f16cdf2)

bug: cluster creation without docker_volume_size

Allows cluster to be created without docker_volume_size where we were
previously seeing this error:

    TypeError: int() argument must be a string,
    a bytes-like object or a number, not 'NoneType'

Regression introduced in https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695239/.

Story: 2005386
Task: 37565

(cherry picked from commit 612b2277769e8e4ac490925c9e01a89cb6b1cb11)

Change-Id: I1bdec0c11a18bea9143fb4792a0a2e4ba5dc1fcf

commit_message:
Build config-drive with novajoin metadata

This change looks for a novajoin endpoint in the catalog, and if it
exists uses metalsmith's NovajoinConfig to call novajoin and populate the
config-drive vendor-data with the response.

NovajoinConfig is subclassed so the configdrive can be built with
genisoimage in the workflow. Ussuri ironic supports vendor_data in the
configdrive json, but Train ironic does not, and this change will need
to be backported to Train.

The unit tests depend on changes which will be in metalsmith-0.16.0

Change-Id: I6cfe74a32636c1dbc205ae32c3146907442dfc9e
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/696993

This subclass of cloud-init config will call the novajoin endpoint and
add the response to the vendordata of the generated config-drive data.

This change also sets instance_info ipa_enroll 'true' so that when
novajoin-listener receives a baremetal node delete notification, it
knows that the node should be unenrolled with FreeIPA.

commit_message:
Implement a instance_config.NovajoinConfig

This subclass of cloud-init config will call the novajoin endpoint and
add the response to the vendordata of the generated config-drive data.

This change also sets instance_info ipa_enroll 'true' so that when
novajoin-listener receives a baremetal node delete notification, it
knows that the node should be unenrolled with FreeIPA.

Change-Id: I1107ce48c2d84b8192dc3b7036350019419c3f54
Blueprint: nova-less-deploy

commit_message:
Move security site to AFS publishing

Move from promoting to static.o.o for the security site to
publish via promote to AFS.

Rename existing promote-security jobs to promote-security-static and
add it to ossa repo so
that we publish to both old and new location. The promote-security-static
job can be removed once everything works.

Create new promote-security job for publishing to AFS.

Story: 2006598
Task: 36854
Change-Id: I18404d8fa79566de1bee1ac5760b8a440e885df8

commit_message:
Enable running unit tests in py37 environment

Until now no unit tests have been executed in py37 environment. This
change fixes tox configuration to enable running these tests.

It also fixes two unit tests to handle PEP479 being enabled for all code
in Python 3.7 [1, 2].

[1] https://docs.python.org/3/whatsnew/3.7.html#changes-in-python-behavior
[2] https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51700960/runtimeerror-generator-raised-stopiteration-every-time-i-try-to-run-app

Change-Id: I7fcf30d848efb8dc4cc6ca19056868aa6127cf60

commit_message:
Update master for stable/train

Add file to the reno documentation build to show release notes for
stable/train.

Use pbr instruction to increment the minor version number
automatically so that master versions are higher than the versions on
stable/train.

Change-Id: Id57d4939da1ea27351d5a5dc5542f24e0abea789
Sem-Ver: feature

commit_message:
Set default-ansible-version to 2.7 for all tenant (minus zuul)

This is to prevent to upgrade of ansible version used by jobs, if / when
zuul project switches from ansible 2.7 to 2.8 for defaults.

Change-Id: I587a70f620bcfb1069508f69df07317d7194025c
Signed-off-by: Paul Belanger <pabelanger@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Replace ostempest job with plain tripleo standalone

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest was added while porting
tripleo ci jobs to os_tempest and now the porting is done.

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest and
tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone are the same job, It replaces the
existing os_tempest job to plain tripleo standalone job to keep
consistency at all places.

Change-Id: I6b987329a55487193d2101b2f3cea7c36eaa7bbc
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix application credential doc example

In 532452f7 we converted the application credential examples to use
python-openstackclient instead of python-keystoneclient, but forgot to
update the prose to go along with it. Correct the client name now.

Change-Id: I6795e42ffc1e9134beedd5fa78d079dba4c5ef42

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

monasca-api is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/

commit_message:
Enable running unit tests in py37 environment

Until now no unit tests have been executed in py37 environment. This
change fixes tox configuration to enable running these tests.

Change-Id: I63bc0309fe6b4b314be97d8fc1bd051d2119ea84

subject: Make tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-undercloud-minion depends on pep
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 21:28:11.000000000', 'message': 'Make tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-undercloud-minion depends on pep

Like other functional jobs, make the new
tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-undercloud-minion to depend on the pep8
job results to avoid consuming resources if pep failed.

Change-Id: I0b986d70bb04c23494d7fb7b59d44441dc77d400
'}]
commit_message:
Make tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-undercloud-minion depends on pep

Like other functional jobs, make the new
tripleo-ci-centos-7-containers-undercloud-minion to depend on the pep8
job results to avoid consuming resources if pep failed.

Change-Id: I0b986d70bb04c23494d7fb7b59d44441dc77d400

commit_message:
Add containerized_undercloud_upgrade var in fs050.

Adding the containerized_undercloud_upgrade variable into
the featureset050, which is used for the undercloud upgrade
job.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/698225

Closes-Bug: #1855856

subject: Add note about ssl ca for minion
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-05 22:34:10.000000000', 'message': "Add note about ssl ca for minion

If the undercloud is configured with ssl, especially the self signed
cert, we need to copy the CA to the minion for functions to work
correctly. We currently don't have this built into the minion
installation so let's handle this with documentation at this time.

Change-Id: I1760a5251df7aba535dfa0fc362fb0100f0f588a
"}]
commit_message:
Add note about ssl ca for minion

If the undercloud is configured with ssl, especially the self signed
cert, we need to copy the CA to the minion for functions to work
correctly. We currently don't have this built into the minion
installation so let's handle this with documentation at this time.

Change-Id: I1760a5251df7aba535dfa0fc362fb0100f0f588a

[{'created': '2019-12-04 14:48:20.000000000', 'message': 'Ensure egress rules include VIP IPs.

Regardless of octavia enforce mode (that affects the loadbalancer
SG rules), the egress rules applied on pods should include the
VIP IPs to ensure the traffic is allowed through them.

Change-Id: Ib695fc44ba090eb455067a04cf5696f9bffcc983
'}]
commit_message:
Ensure egress rules include VIP IPs.

Regardless of octavia enforce mode (that affects the loadbalancer
SG rules), the egress rules applied on pods should include the
VIP IPs to ensure the traffic is allowed through them.

Change-Id: Ib695fc44ba090eb455067a04cf5696f9bffcc983

subject: Enable devstack force=yes for xenial based jobs

commit_message:
Enable devstack force=yes for xenial based jobs

A recent devstack patch[1] causes jobs running on xenial based
nodesets to fail due to xenial no longer being supported.
This patch adds the FORCE=yes for devstack on jobs that are voting
and using xenial nodesets due to compatiblity issues.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/695114/

Change-Id: I8f17b0f0e5d7dfa82da22b010e7090b9ce3d2cb0

commit_message:
CI: disable IPv6 in neutron

Sadly, our devstack plugin still does not work with IPv6. We're now
seeing an increasingly high number of gate failures due to a node
only receiving an IPv6 address from neutron. Disable IPv6 until
we can solve it (help needed!).

This patch temporary disables rescue. It's broken in IPA, and we
cannot land a fix because of the IPv6 problem.

Change-Id: I02078ef9a542d160f437c5989557ed3ea7346cf1

commit_message:
Add support to configure vhost-iommu-support

This change adds ability to add vhost-iommu-support
parameter to openvswitch configuration.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-12 09:53:15.000000000', 'message': '[WIP] Support power state change callbacks to nova

Questions/Clarifications:

1) Should we do callbacks for all power state changes? Yes as
   per previous discussions. Current logic is to send the event
   from "node_power_action" method which seems to be the centrally
   used function for changing power state from everywhere. Will
   this be an overkill? Apart from that there are some special
   cases to clarify:

a) What if the state change is coming from nova itself i.e
   a nova start/stop action: this patch currently still sends
   the event and on the nova side it will be a no-op with a
   debug log saying the node is already powering on/off.
b) power state changes to nodes in maintenance will also be
   sent without discretion to maintain consistency.
c) power state changes during ironic power sync will be sent to
   nova irrespective of the "force_power_state_during_sync"
   config option.
d) power state changes via ironic CLI (baremetal node on/off)
   will also be sent to nova so that an instance shutdown by
   nova can be brought up through ironic.
e) Are we missing something?

NOTE: There can be a race scenario if the nova-ironic power sync
happens to happen a nano-second before the power state change
event is received from ironic.

TODO:
This is a WIP that needs tests. Not ready for review.
Add a release note, depends on etc.. for the dependency on
python-novaclient version.

Change-Id: I6d105524e1645d9a40dfeae2850c33cf2d110826
Story: 2004969
Task: 29424
'}, {'created': '2019-06-24 11:54:07.000000000', 'message': 'Support power state change callbacks to nova

Add power state change callbacks of an instance to nova by
performing API requests. Whenever there is a change in the
power state of a physical instance (example a "power on"
or "power off" IPMI command is issued or the periodic
``_sync_power_states`` task detects a change in power state)
ironic will create and send a ``power-update`` external event
to nova using which nova will update the power state of the
instance in its database. By conveying the power state changes
to nova, ironic becomes the source of truth thus preventing
nova from forcing wrong power states on the instance during
the nova-ironic periodic sync. It also adds the possibility of
bringing up/down a physical instance through the ironic API
even if it was put down/up through the nova API.

Note that ironic only sends requests to nova if the target
power state is either "power on" or "power off". Other error
states will be ignored. In cases where the power state change
is originally coming from nova, the event will still be
created and sent to nova and on the nova side it will be a
no-op with a debug log saying the node is already powering on/off.

NOTE: Although an exclusive lock (task_manager.upgrade_lock()
method) is used when sending calling the nova API to send events,
there can still be a race condition if the nova-ironic power sync
happens to happen a nano-second before the power state change
event is received from ironic in which case the nova state will
be forced on the node.

'}, {'created': '2019-06-24 15:01:30.000000000', 'message': 'Support power state change callbacks to nova

Add power state change callbacks of an instance to nova by
performing API requests. Whenever there is a change in the
power state of a physical instance (example a "power on"
or "power off" IPMI command is issued or the periodic
``_sync_power_states`` task detects a change in power state)
ironic will create and send a ``power-update`` external event
to nova using which nova will update the power state of the
instance in its database. By conveying the power state changes
to nova, ironic becomes the source of truth thus preventing
nova from forcing wrong power states on the instance during
the nova-ironic periodic sync. It also adds the possibility of
bringing up/down a physical instance through the ironic API
even if it was put down/up through the nova API.

Note that ironic only sends requests to nova if the target
power state is either "power on" or "power off". Other error
states will be ignored. In cases where the power state change
is originally coming from nova, the event will still be
created and sent to nova and on the nova side it will be a
no-op with a debug log saying the node is already powering on/off.

NOTE: Although an exclusive lock (task_manager.upgrade_lock()
method) is used when sending calling the nova API to send events,
there can still be a race condition if the nova-ironic power sync
happens to happen a nano-second before the power state change
event is received from ironic in which case the nova state will
be forced on the node.

TODO: Release python-novaclient 14.2.0 after the nova side change
is merged.

Add power state change callbacks of an instance to nova by
performing API requests. Whenever there is a change in the
power state of a physical instance (example a "power on"
or "power off" IPMI command is issued or the periodic
``_sync_power_states`` task detects a change in power state)
ironic will create and send a ``power-update`` external event
to nova using which nova will update the power state of the
instance in its database. By conveying the power state changes
to nova, ironic becomes the source of truth thus preventing
nova from forcing wrong power states on the instance during
the nova-ironic periodic sync. It also adds the possibility of
bringing up/down a physical instance through the ironic API
even if it was put down/up through the nova API.

Note that ironic only sends requests to nova if the target
power state is either "power on" or "power off". Other error
states will be ignored. In cases where the power state change
is originally coming from nova, the event will still be
created and sent to nova and on the nova side it will be a
no-op with a debug log saying the node is already powering on/off.

NOTE: Although an exclusive lock (task_manager.upgrade_lock()
method) is used when calling the nova API to send events,
there can still be a race condition if the nova-ironic power sync
happens to happen a nano-second before the power state change
event is received from ironic in which case the nova state will
be forced on the node.

Credit for introducing ksa adapter: Eric Fried <openstack@fried.cc>
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/645611/
Part of blueprint nova-support-instance-power-update
Story: 2004969
Task: 29424

commit_message:
Support power state change callbacks to nova using ksa_adapter

Add power state change callbacks of an instance to nova by
performing API requests. Whenever there is a change in the
power state of a physical instance (example a "power on"
or "power off" IPMI command is issued or the periodic
``_sync_power_states`` task detects a change in power state)
ironic will create and send a ``power-update`` external event
to nova using which nova will update the power state of the
instance in its database. By conveying the power state changes
to nova, ironic becomes the source of truth thus preventing
nova from forcing wrong power states on the instance during
the nova-ironic periodic sync. It also adds the possibility of
bringing up/down a physical instance through the ironic API
even if it was put down/up through the nova API.

Note that ironic only sends requests to nova if the target
power state is either "power on" or "power off". Other error
states will be ignored. In cases where the power state change
is originally coming from nova, the event will still be
created and sent to nova and on the nova side it will be a
no-op with a debug log saying the node is already powering on/off.

NOTE: Although an exclusive lock (task_manager.upgrade_lock()
method) is used when calling the nova API to send events,
there can still be a race condition if the nova-ironic power sync
happens to happen a nano-second before the power state change
event is received from ironic in which case the nova state will
be forced on the node.

Credit for introducing ksa adapter: Eric Fried <openstack@fried.cc>
Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/645611/
Part of blueprint nova-support-instance-power-update
Story: 2004969
Task: 29424

Change-Id: I6d105524e1645d9a40dfeae2850c33cf2d110826

Ack. Right now, I'm still torn as to risks/benefits of backporting it. For sure, any fix compatible with minor update will at least trigger a one-time restart to update the pacemaker configuration."}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-03 15:13:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

As a heads up, I'm gonna test this high-level plan for allowing backports:

  . define a new Heat parameter "ClusterCommonTag" which defaults to false.

  . when set to false, we keep using the current image naming scheme: "<registry/imagename:pcmklatest>". That way, minor updates will work as today and won't trigger any restart.

  . if a user really requires that feature, he will need to run a stack update with Heat parameter "ClusterCommonTag" set to true. This should pull all images on all nodes before the pacemaker config is updated to use the new naming scheme. This will cause a one-time restart of all ha services, so user must be aware of that.

In another review, figure out a way to make this Heat parameter default to true during major upgrade.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-06 19:32:22.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:19:01.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:26:23.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Tested locally and this does what is expected:
  . new deployment keeps using the original naming scheme

  . minor update doesn't change the naming scheme and doesn't cause any unexpected resource restart

  . stack update with Heat parameter ClusterCommonTag set to true reconfigures all HA services, make them all restart, and at the end of the update, the new naming scheme is in use.

  . new deployment with Heat  parameter ClusterCommonTag set to true results in a HA overcloud using the new naming scheme"}, {'account_id': 20778, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:32:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4:

[{'created': '2019-12-02 12:02:44.000000000', 'message': 'WIP HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01
'}, {'created': '2019-12-03 14:08:52.000000000', 'message': 'HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

HA services get their container image name from a pacemaker
resource configuration. This image name is shared between
all cluster nodes.

To achieve image update without service disruption, a pacemaker
resource is configured to use a "floating" tag
<registry/imagename:pcmklatest> pointing to the real image
name configured in Heat.

During a rolling update, when a container image is updated, one just
needs to make the floating tag point to the latest image in the
container engine. This way, there is no need to update the pacemaker
resource configuration (which cannot hold two different image names
concurrently).

Generalize this approach by using a "floating" image name entirely
instead of only a floating tag (:pcmklatest suffix). This way, any
arbitrary image name can be used during a rolling update.

Note: by doing so, we stop seeing a meaningful image name prefix
in "pcs status", but since we already can't tell what the floating
tag is pointing to in pcs, we don't lose much information really.

Tested by deploying a 3-node HA overcloud, and running a minor update
with new image name.

Closes-Bug: #1854730

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01
'}, {'created': '2019-12-06 19:32:22.000000000', 'message': 'HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

HA services get their container image name from a pacemaker
resource configuration. This image name is shared between
all cluster nodes.

To achieve image update without service disruption, a pacemaker
resource is configured to use an intermediate image name
"<registry>/<namespace>/<servicename>:pcmklatest" pointing to
the real image name configured in Heat. This tag can then be
updated independently on every node during the minor update.

In order to support the same rolling update when the <namespace>
changes in the container image, we need a similar floating
approach for the prefix part of the container image.

Introduce a new Heat parameter ClusterCommonTag that, when enabled,
sets the intermediate image name to
"container-common-tag/<servicename>:pcmklatest". By default, this
parameter is disabled and the original naming scheme is conserved.

Note: by introducing this new naming scheme, we stop seeing a
meaningful image name prefix when doing a "pcs status", but since
we already can't tell what image ID the :pcmklatest tag points to,
we don't lose much information really.

Related-Bug: #1854730

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01

commit_message:
HA: minor update of arbitrary container image name

HA services get their container image name from a pacemaker
resource configuration. This image name is shared between
all cluster nodes.

To achieve image update without service disruption, a pacemaker
resource is configured to use an intermediate image name
"<registry>/<namespace>/<servicename>:pcmklatest" pointing to
the real image name configured in Heat. This tag can then be
updated independently on every node during the minor update.

In order to support the same rolling update when the <namespace>
changes in the container image, we need a similar floating
approach for the prefix part of the container image.

Introduce a new Heat parameter ClusterCommonTag that, when enabled,
sets the intermediate image name to
"cluster-common-tag/<servicename>:pcmklatest". By default, this
parameter is disabled and the original naming scheme is conserved.

Note: by introducing this new naming scheme, we stop seeing a
meaningful image name prefix when doing a "pcs status", but since
we already can't tell what image ID the :pcmklatest tag points to,
we don't lose much information really.

Related-Bug: #1854730

Change-Id: Id369154d147cd5cf0a6f997bf806084fc7580e01

commit_message:
Adds --all-cells to the archive command

Adds --all-cells to the archive command based on an empty_table
boolean flag. If true, it will run in archive command on all
configured cells.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/697012

Change-Id: Iaa47181318eb8b9251d47fd381784791f4967a4e
(cherry picked from commit bb08feae87642519524f2fa233e88cb65ee7bae8)

commit_message:
Start README.rst with a better title

Now that we are using gitea the contents of our README.rst are
more prominently displayed. Starting it with a "Team and repository
tags" title is a bit confusing. This change makes it start with the
name of the project instead.

While at it, make intro more user-friendly and point to CONTRIBUTING.rst
instead of HACKING.rst for contributor guidance.

Change-Id: I1a7044ea10b94cdb25dfcc05d3b2b77d877c1dd5

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-26 12:12:18.000000000', 'message': 'HA: make default operation timeout configurable

Currently, pacemaker has no specific configuration to tweak
the bundle monitor operation timeout, so changing that timeout
can only be achieved by modifying the default operation timeout.

Make the default operation timeout configurable via a new hiera
key. This is needed for monitoring podman containers when the
cluster is under IO load, to prevent the default timeout (20s)
to kick in, to trigger unnecessary bundle restart, and to
destabilize the control plane.

Change-Id: I79fd06ec0fa7e1881d5276d8b7b4b9e568313509
Closes-Bug: #1834325
'}]
commit_message:
HA: make default operation timeout configurable

Currently, pacemaker has no specific configuration to tweak
the bundle monitor operation timeout, so changing that timeout
can only be achieved by modifying the default operation timeout.

Make the default operation timeout configurable via a new hiera
key. This is needed for monitoring podman containers when the
cluster is under IO load, to prevent the default timeout (20s)
to kick in, to trigger unnecessary bundle restart, and to
destabilize the control plane.

Change-Id: I79fd06ec0fa7e1881d5276d8b7b4b9e568313509
Closes-Bug: #1834325

[{'created': '2019-11-27 14:54:58.000000000', 'message': "Support configuration of Docker client timeout

Adds support for configuration of the Docker client timeout via
'docker_client_timeout'. The default timeout is 60 seconds.  Increasing
this may be helpful in cases where Docker reports 'Read timed out'.

This change also increases this timeout to 120 seconds in CI testing,
as we often see timeouts there.

Change-Id: I73745771078cb2c0ebae2b1d87ba2c4c12958d82
Closes-Bug: #1809844
"}, {'created': '2019-11-28 10:10:04.000000000', 'message': "Support configuration of Docker client timeout

Adds support for configuration of the Docker client timeout via
'docker_client_timeout'.

This change also increases the default timeout to 120 seconds, as we
sometimes see timeouts in CI and heavily loaded or underpowered
environments. Increasing 'docker_client_timeout' further may be helpful
in cases where Docker reports 'Read timed out'.

Change-Id: I73745771078cb2c0ebae2b1d87ba2c4c12958d82
Closes-Bug: #1809844
"}]
commit_message:
Support configuration of Docker client timeout

Adds support for configuration of the Docker client timeout via
'docker_client_timeout'.

This change also increases the default timeout to 120 seconds, as we
sometimes see timeouts in CI and heavily loaded or underpowered
environments. Increasing 'docker_client_timeout' further may be helpful
in cases where Docker reports 'Read timed out'.

Change-Id: I73745771078cb2c0ebae2b1d87ba2c4c12958d82
Closes-Bug: #1809844

commit_message:
dns_integration: allow networks with router:external=True

There is no valid reason why we're blocking creating records for
networks that have router:external=True.  We allow settting the
dns_domain and dns_name field for floating IPs (for reverse DNS)
and therefore in an environment where instances can be plugged
directly to an external network, it makes sense to also offer
that option.

Partial-Bug: #1784879
Change-Id: I4834bced574065e06978833da63f618dc15fe88a

tmpwatch is installed from within its own file:
https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/deployment/logrotate/tmpwatch-install.yaml'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2019-12-10 12:48:17.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Hi Cdric,

Thanks for your feedback.
As you pointed out we have tmpwatch installed in tmpwatch-install.yaml, but the problem is that we don't enable the resource on overcloud nodes.

https://opendev.org/openstack/tripleo-heat-templates/src/branch/master/overcloud-resource-registry-puppet.j2.yaml#L328

IMO, to have tmpwatch installed on the deployed nodes (for example nodes initially deployed with the overclud image that does not include tmpwatch), we also enable the resource for overcloud nodes, and I'll update my patch to address that.
May I ask your thought about that?

Thank you,
Takashi"}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2019-12-10 13:01:33.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 9816, 'date': '2019-12-10 13:46:31.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

commit_message:
Run tmpwatch installation also for overcloud nodes

Currently we need tmpwatch package is introduced in overcloud,
but we can miss it if the overcloud nodes are deployed with the image
which does not include tmpwatch packages.

This patch make sure to enable OS::TripleO::Service::Tmpwatch resource
not only for undercloud/standalone node but also for overcloud nodes
to make sure that we have tmpwatch installed on overcloud nodes.

Change-Id: I715f133ef446b061b36de0b83048848712b2ab05
Closes-Bug: #1855802

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-07-18 18:54:41.000000000', 'message': 'Replace "integrated-gate-py3" template with new "integrated-gate-storage"

tempest-full-py3 job run all services API and scenario tests (non slow)
and this job is part of Integrated-gate-py3 gate template which run on
multiple services (nova, neutron, cinder, glance, placement, swift, keystone)
check and gate pipeline.
Due to all services tests run in single tempest-full-py3 job, it has
been not so stable. Many times unrelated service test break other
project gate.

But not all those services are dependent of Glance. Dependent in term of
both way, not all services used by Glance or use Glance. Glance gate
does not need to run all those independent services tests. It can run only
Cinder, Glance, Swift and Nova related tests.

Idea here is to make integrated-gate testing more stable without losing
the test coverage.

Tempest has new "integrated-gate-storage" template which will run only
Cinder, Glance, Swift and Nova related tests[1].

This commit replaces the "integrated-gate-py3" template with new
"integrated-gate-storage".

ML discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005871.html

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/branch/master/.zuul.yaml#L626

Change-Id: I4f858cd3b5b18be56acd6dbf79440e1cd8ce2744
'}]
commit_message:
Replace "integrated-gate-py3" template with new "integrated-gate-storage"

tempest-full-py3 job run all services API and scenario tests (non slow)
and this job is part of Integrated-gate-py3 gate template which run on
multiple services (nova, neutron, cinder, glance, placement, swift, keystone)
check and gate pipeline.
Due to all services tests run in single tempest-full-py3 job, it has
been not so stable. Many times unrelated service test break other
project gate.

But not all those services are dependent of Glance. Dependent in term of
both way, not all services used by Glance or use Glance. Glance gate
does not need to run all those independent services tests. It can run only
Cinder, Glance, Swift and Nova related tests.

Idea here is to make integrated-gate testing more stable without losing
the test coverage.

Tempest has new "integrated-gate-storage" template which will run only
Cinder, Glance, Swift and Nova related tests[1].

This commit replaces the "integrated-gate-py3" template with new
"integrated-gate-storage".

ML discussion: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-May/005871.html

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/tempest/src/branch/master/.zuul.yaml#L626

Change-Id: I4f858cd3b5b18be56acd6dbf79440e1cd8ce2744

This reverts the following commits:

d866c63a32a494b8643b166c3b1e36e463a7502f
6b40b655f124d0a95f1b7d89ce04236606a02010

source images until CentOS 8 / python 3 support is available and
working.

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 14:21:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone bootstrap error message display

In some situations, Keystone bootstrap can fail, and then unhelpfully
fails displaying the error message output by the 'keystone-manage
bootstrap' command. This appears to be due to unprintable control
characters in the error message which prevent the output of the script
from being valid JSON.

This change fixes the issue by piping the output through 'cat -v', which
replaces unprintable characters with control codes.

Change-Id: I82444bc2272311023cc9e92c5a298d1c4c87483b
Closes-Bug: #1855701
(cherry picked from commit bcca3fabe305c1e206fdb231c31809ceff2d4774)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone bootstrap error message display

In some situations, Keystone bootstrap can fail, and then unhelpfully
fails displaying the error message output by the 'keystone-manage
bootstrap' command. This appears to be due to unprintable control
characters in the error message which prevent the output of the script
from being valid JSON.

This change fixes the issue by piping the output through 'cat -v', which
replaces unprintable characters with control codes.

Change-Id: I82444bc2272311023cc9e92c5a298d1c4c87483b
Closes-Bug: #1855701
(cherry picked from commit bcca3fabe305c1e206fdb231c31809ceff2d4774)

commit_message:
Set maximum buffer size for Kafka producer

The change sets queue.buffering.max.messages configuration option for
Kafka producer effectively limiting the number of messages in the buffer
before sending them to Apache Kafka.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/694738
Change-Id: I6ebd4e21e9d55d1ac836e92dd8bf02a678170c68
Story: 2006059
Task: 37532

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-07 08:18:34.000000000', 'message': 'Clear skb mark on encapsulating packets

Looks like by default OVS tunnels inherit skb marks from
tunneled packets. As a result Neutron IPTables marks set in
qrouter namespace are inherited by VXLAN encapsulating packets.
These marks may conflict with marks used by underlying networking
(like Calico) and lead to VXLAN tunneled packets being dropped.

This patch ensures that skb marks are cleared by OVS before entering
a tunnel to avoid conflicts with IPTables rules in default namespace.

Closes-Bug: #1839252
Change-Id: Id029be51bffe4188dd7f2155db16b21d19da1698
'}]
commit_message:
Clear skb mark on encapsulating packets

Looks like by default OVS tunnels inherit skb marks from
tunneled packets. As a result Neutron IPTables marks set in
qrouter namespace are inherited by VXLAN encapsulating packets.
These marks may conflict with marks used by underlying networking
(like Calico) and lead to VXLAN tunneled packets being dropped.

This patch ensures that skb marks are cleared by OVS before entering
a tunnel to avoid conflicts with IPTables rules in default namespace.

Closes-Bug: #1839252
Change-Id: Id029be51bffe4188dd7f2155db16b21d19da1698

reviewers: [{'_account_id': 7353, 'name': 'Kevin Carter', 'email': 'kevin@cloudnull.com', 'username': 'cloudnull'}, {'_account_id': 14985, 'name': 'Alex Schultz', 'email': 'aschultz@next-development.com', 'username': 'mwhahaha'}, {'_account_id': 18575, 'name': 'Saravanan KR', 'email': 'krsacme@gmail.com', 'username': 'saravanankr'}, {'_account_id': 22348, 'name': 'Zuul', 'username': 'zuul', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}, {'_account_id': 23181, 'name': 'RDO Third Party CI', 'email': 'dmsimard+rdothirdparty@redhat.com', 'username': 'rdothirdparty', 'tags': ['SERVICE_USER']}]
