subject: Add COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait
messages:
[{'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-20 14:58:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-06-20 18:12:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

We may want to hold off on this for a bit until there is at least some general agreement on using this for pre-filtering host during cold migration in nova or if there are alternatives for that problem (or if it's not a problem worth solving)."}, {'account_id': 11564, 'date': '2019-07-03 12:07:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This seems like a potentially good idea, but I've got a bit of a concern about how much smarts/contextual awareness become required in the pre-filtering stage. Each pre-filter trait means more awareness.

Which isn't the worst thing ever, "needing a lot of contextual awareness in the code" is how nova is spelt, but...'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-26 23:07:38.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm not even sure that it would be a pre-filter per se. The code in the compute API that handles cold migration and checks the allow_resize_to_same_host flag determines whether or not the RequestSpec should ignore the current instance.host or not. If allow_resize_to_same_host=True, then the API could pull the resource provider for the current instance.host/node and check if it has this trait and if not, ignore the current instance.host despite the allow_resize_to_same_host config option since it's not until we get to the compute today that we check the supports_migrate_to_same_host capability on the driver and fail for everything except vCenter.

That's my idea anyway, but I haven't fleshed it out with an actual nova change that has functional testing to recreate the issue and all that."}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-27 00:43:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

im not entirely following the logic.
would it not be less expecive to check the compute node capablites within nova then to retrive the compute node RP traits?

i guess withine nova the api would have to down call to the cell db to retirve the compute service object to determing the compute capablities of the driver so i guess an api call to placemnt cpuld be less expensive then rabbitmq.

but the bit that consuses me is do you intend to inject COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE as a requried or forbiden trait?

if not im not sure if it would be a trait as it feels more like metadata storage then a plamcnet requirement.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 17:16:47.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

So what we actually need is for this code [1] to be able to say something more like:

 if not (CONF.allow_resize_to_same_host and can_resize_to_self(instance.host)):
     filter_properties['ignore_hosts'].append(instance.host)

...and this trait suggests you want to do it via

 def can_resize_to_self(host):
    return (os_traits.COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE in
            placement.get("/resource_providers/%s/traits" % host.uuid).json()['traits'])

(Except host.uuid isn't a thing because host is a string hostname, so you'd have to get the host UUID some other way, either from the database or with another placement call.)

But I don't see any way to use this in a required/forbidden trait filter. That just wouldn't make sense.

So at the very least I'm going to downvote until that ^ (or whatever the actual intent is) is better explained in the commit message. Which kind of seems to be what Sean and maybe Chris have been asking as well.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/1599e3cf68779eafaaa2b13a273d3bebd1379c19/nova/compute/api.py#L3562-L3563'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-12 19:42:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-08-12 21:33:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

More discussion about this here:

https://review.opendev.org/#/c/675025/'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 20:31:52.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

This https://review.opendev.org/#/c/676022/ adds a workaround option to get us over the hump in the API if you want to enable allow_resize_to_same_host=True but need to also disable cold migration to the same host. We could remove that workaround option by checking if the instance host/node provider has the COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait for same-host cold migration (vcenter would be the only driver that reports it).'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 20:37:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> (Except host.uuid isn't a thing because host is a string hostname, so you'd have to get the host UUID some other way, either from the database or with another placement call.)

We'd get the resource provider via uuid using the ComputeNode.uuid using the instance.host/node values for the instance that is being resized/migrated. Note that we'd only need to do this in the cold migrate case since we already have the allow_resize_to_same_host option in nova.

> But I don't see any way to use this in a required/forbidden trait filter. That just wouldn't make sense.

If you're thinking this would be part of a flavor or image required/forbidden trait, it wouldn't be. This wouldn't be a pre-request filter thing in the scheduler. And since it only applies to cold migrate, and the flavor doesn't change on cold migrate, it doesn't make sense to be on the flavor anyway. It would just be something the compute API checks and adjusts the RequestSpec appropriately which will then filter out returned allocation candidates appropriately here:

https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/1599e3cf68779eafaaa2b13a273d3bebd1379c19/nova/scheduler/host_manager.py#L593

Granted if nova pre-filtered allocation candidates using the trait that would be faster but I don't think it's necessary for version 1 of how the compute API could use this."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 20:45:54.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 2: Commit message was updated.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-19 20:51:18.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-19 23:06:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

Sorry, you're going to have to walk me through this.

I think I see how *nova* (not placement) can do something like:

 for candidate in `GET /a_c`:
     if (    candidate.host == source.host and
             allow_resize_to_same_host and
             is_cold_migrate and not
             host_has_trait(candidate, COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE)):
         # Same-host cold migrate is not supported
         continue

But I don't see how the trait could *ever* be passed to GET /a_c itself for this use case. Am I missing something here, or is that correct?"}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-20 14:52:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> But I don't see how the trait could *ever* be passed to GET /a_c itself for this use case. Am I missing something here, or is that correct?

As I tried to explain in the commit message, at least initially, nova wouldn't be even using this trait in the scheduler, so GET /allocation_candidates is not involved. The compute API would be using this to modify the RequestSpec which *is* used by the scheduler to filter candidates we get back from placement."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-20 15:30:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

Here is a PoC for nova and how I thought about using this which hopefully clears up the confusion:

https://review.opendev.org/695220'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-11-20 16:32:59.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2: Code-Review-1

Haven't looked at the PoC yet, but this:

>  nova wouldn't be even using this trait in the scheduler, so GET /allocation_candidates is not involved
...
> filter candidates we get back from placement.

...is what I was confirming. It's not clear from the commit message, particularly "if nova could make a better decision during
scheduling by asking placement for only compute nodes that support
this type of operation". Even in context (esp. because of "In absence of the trait, nova can workaround...") this implied (to me) that we might eventually be able to do that.

Knowing the actual use case, IMO the existence of the trait is justified anyway. But I would really like it to be made clear in the commit message *and* the code comment next to the actual trait def that we explicitly don't expect it to ever make sense for this trait to be used as a required/forbidden filter to placement itself. +2 if that happens.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:42:37.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

> that we explicitly don't expect it to ever make sense for this trait to be used as a required/forbidden filter to placement itself

I'm not explicitly ruling that out though. I could implement things in nova in such a way that the trait could be hacked into the request spec that we send to the scheduler as a forbidden trait if same-host cold migrate is not supported. That's a hack but it would do the pre-filtering (in placement) rather than post-filtering (in the scheduler host manager) and the latter is what my PoC is doing since it's simple."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-11-21 15:43:41.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

I also don't think it's really appropriate to leave comments in os-traits about how the trait may or may not be used by anything consuming it - that's super far away tight coupling IMO."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:37:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

> > that we explicitly don't expect it to ever make sense for this trait to be used as a required/forbidden filter to placement itself
> I'm not explicitly ruling that out though. I could implement things in nova in such a way that the trait could be hacked into the request spec that we send to the scheduler as a forbidden trait if same-host cold migrate is not supported. That's a hack but it would do the pre-filtering (in placement) rather than post-filtering (in the scheduler host manager) and the latter is what my PoC is doing since it's simple.

No dude, I'm saying that *will not work*, ever, period. That would only mean that *all* hosts supporting same-host cold migrate would be excluded from the results. That doesn't make sense in this context, and there's no context where it will ever make sense. Having a comment to that effect in here just makes it simpler for future me to remember that reasoning any time someone proposes the patch to "improve" your post-filter by making it a placement request filter.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:43:21.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 2:

OK I think I see where I was missing you.

Taking libvirt computes as the basic example since that's the reference driver everyone uses and wouldn't have COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE on it's providers.

If I try to cold migrate a server and it's on a libvirt node, it won't have the COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait so if we made a GET /allocation_candidates?COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE=forbidden call, we'd still get back the libvirt source node potentially since it doesn't have the trait. The only nodes we wouldn't get back are those that have the trait, which for nova would be vcenter nodes. So yeah I see what you're saying now."}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 19:47:24.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 20:02:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-05 20:03:21.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 20:07:56.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 3.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-05 20:08:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 2:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-12-05 20:09:44.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:10:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 3: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:10:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Patch Set 3 was rebased'}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:11:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

Actually, should we hold off merging this until the main patch is no longer WIP or is this definitely the approach we'll be going with?"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:35:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review+1

long term we will have the trait i think in anycase.
it is a capability that can be reported by clustered hypervisors.

regarding if we should wait or not the depend on relationship should
be the inverse e.g. the nova code depneds on this. we could wait for it to be non work in progress but i dont think we have a better long term solution then the trait at the moment.

even if we were to come up with a non traits based solution i think the trait is still reasonable but im kind of neutral on merging now or waiting.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:44:12.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

> even if we were to come up with a non traits based solution i think the trait is still reasonable but im kind of neutral on merging now or waiting.

The hack alternative to not using the trait in nova is if we're doing a cold migration get the compute node object for the instance and check it's hypervisor_type and if it's vcenter then allow cold migrate to the same host else disallow. That doesn't necessarily mean it fixes any out of tree drivers though, e.g. the hyperv cluster driver."}, {'account_id': 15334, 'date': '2019-12-09 17:25:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Workflow+1

I was less concerned about whether this was a good idea and more whether it would actually get done because $OtherHigherPriorityStuff exists. I guess if will and if it doesn't, this will just end up being noise. Let's plough on"}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-06-20 14:58:56.000000000', 'message': 'Add COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait

This adds a compute capability trait to model the
nova ComputeDriver supports_migrate_to_same_host capability [1].

There is a latent bug in nova where configuring the
allow_resize_to_same_host option to True can potentially
lead the scheduler to pick the same host the server is on
to start a cold migration which is only supported by the
(in-tree) vCenter driver (since that driver manages a vCenter
cluster of ESXi hosts). This can lead to at best the cold migration
flow picking an alternate host and at worst failing the cold migration.
Either is not desirable if nova could make a better decision during
scheduling by asking placement for only compute nodes that support
this type of operation.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/driver.py#L153

Change-Id: I29ef5c402e0d006518bfce14f616e58f85ce7c9d
Related-Bug: #1819216
'}, {'created': '2019-11-19 20:45:54.000000000', 'message': "Add COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait

This adds a compute capability trait to model the
nova ComputeDriver supports_migrate_to_same_host capability [1].

There is a latent bug in nova where configuring the
allow_resize_to_same_host option to True can potentially
lead the scheduler to pick the same host the server is on
to start a cold migration which is only supported by the
(in-tree) vCenter driver (since that driver manages a vCenter
cluster of ESXi hosts). This can lead to at best the cold migration
flow picking an alternate host and at worst failing the cold migration.
Either is not desirable if nova could make a better decision during
scheduling by asking placement for only compute nodes that support
this type of operation.

In absence of the trait, nova can workaround the issue with a
config option [2] such that when cold migrating the API can determine
if the current host that the instance is on should be ignored during
scheduling. With the trait, nova could deprecate and remove that workaround
by having the compute API determine if the host that the instance is on
is suitable for same-host cold migration by finding the provider using
the ComputeNode related to the instance (via host/node on the instance)
and if that provider has the COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait. That
would still leave the nova scheduler to filter out allocation candidates
using the RequestSpec.ignore_hosts list as it does today but it's better
than using a global config option in the API which could be wrong for a
mixed hypervisor deployment. Long-term nova may be able to pre-filter the
allocation candidates using the forbidden trait if the RequestSpec is
modified (but not persisted) with the appropriate info for the cold
migrate operation, e.g. hack the forbidden trait into the Flavor object
embedded in the RequestSpec.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/driver.py#L153
[2] https://review.opendev.org/676022/

Change-Id: I29ef5c402e0d006518bfce14f616e58f85ce7c9d
Related-Bug: #1748697

In absence of the trait, nova can workaround the issue with a

commit_message:
Add COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait

This adds a compute capability trait to model the
nova ComputeDriver supports_migrate_to_same_host capability [1].

There is a latent bug in nova where configuring the
allow_resize_to_same_host option to True can potentially
lead the scheduler to pick the same host the server is on
to start a cold migration which is only supported by the
(in-tree) vCenter driver (since that driver manages a vCenter
cluster of ESXi hosts). This can lead to at best the cold migration
flow picking an alternate host and at worst failing the cold migration.
Either is not desirable if nova could make a better decision during
scheduling by asking placement for only compute nodes that support
this type of operation.

In absence of the trait, nova can workaround the issue with a
config option [2] such that when cold migrating the API can determine
if the current host that the instance is on should be ignored during
scheduling. With the trait, nova could deprecate and remove that workaround
by having the compute API determine if the host that the instance is on
is suitable for same-host cold migration by finding the provider using
the ComputeNode related to the instance (via host/node on the instance)
and if that provider has the COMPUTE_SAME_HOST_COLD_MIGRATE trait [3]. That
would still leave the nova scheduler to filter out allocation candidates
using the RequestSpec.ignore_hosts list as it does today but it's better
than using a global config option in the API which could be wrong for a
mixed hypervisor deployment.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/19.0.0/nova/virt/driver.py#L153
[2] https://review.opendev.org/676022/
[3] https://review.opendev.org/695220/

Change-Id: I29ef5c402e0d006518bfce14f616e58f85ce7c9d
Related-Bug: #1748697

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-27 16:43:00.000000000', 'message': 'Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
'}, {'created': '2019-12-06 20:27:12.000000000', 'message': 'Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
(cherry picked from commit 5e858d0cbd672639318543201e251ed00324a9c2)
'}]
commit_message:
Do not update root_device_name during guest config

_get_guest_config() is currently updating instance.root_device_name
and called in many ways like:

_hard_reboot(), rescue(), spawn(), resume(), finish_migration(),
finish_revert_migration()

It is an issue because root_device_name is initally set during instance
build and should remain the same after:

manager.py: _do_build_and_run_instance()
             ..
               _default_block_device_names() <-here
               ..
               driver.spawn()

This may lead to edge case, like in rescue where this value can be mistakenly
updated to reflect disk bus property of rescue image (hw_disk_bus).
Further more, a _get* method should not modify instance object.

Note that test test_get_guest_config_bug_1118829 is removed because no more
relevant with current code.

Change-Id: I1787f9717618d0837208844e8065840d30341cf7
Closes-Bug: #1835926
(cherry picked from commit 5e0ed5e7fee3c4c887263a0e9fa847c2dcc5cf3b)
(cherry picked from commit 5e858d0cbd672639318543201e251ed00324a9c2)

[{'created': '2019-11-26 17:50:32.000000000', 'message': 'Support python 3 in kolla-ansible script

The kolla-ansible script uses a python interpreter to detect the
location of playbooks and to check that the kolla_ansible python module
is importable. This change updates the script to support a python
interpreter named python3 or python.

Partially Implements: blueprint python-3

commit_message:
Support python 3 in kolla-ansible script

The kolla-ansible script uses a python interpreter to detect the
location of playbooks and to check that the kolla_ansible python module
is importable. This change updates the script to support a python
interpreter named python or python3.

Partially Implements: blueprint python-3

Change-Id: Id5dcc53cc5dd9780632c04b6b73c56ea5da484a2

commit_message:
Add fallback option when stating the source file

This change will now fall back to using the ansible core module
`stat` to stat a file when the local stat function fails for a
permissions error. This is being done because there is an issue
with action plugins not respecting "become: true" on local files
being written over a local connection.

Change-Id: I646f0688f1f4bf3cddaef9114dac51c2a807b25b
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Remove deprecated filters

Due to the placement service being moved out of nova some filters
should no longer be used. Removed filters deprecated in Train.
See:
https://docs.openstack.org/nova/train/admin/configuration/schedulers.html

Change-Id: I1f890f85e0fadaf36ae0c638fb4885a763beae0b

subject: Fix AttributeError in negotiate_version
messages: [{'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-12-04 11:25:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 14826, 'date': '2019-12-04 11:26:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked\n\nThis patchset was cherry picked to branch stable/stein as commit 0bd26cc47ed51d19e07280db9e770ad09edd2bf8'}, {'account_id': 23851, 'date': '2019-12-05 11:02:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 10206, 'date': '2019-12-06 06:00:04.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6618, 'date': '2019-12-09 15:25:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-04 11:25:39.000000000', 'message': "Fix AttributeError in negotiate_version

Seen in kolla-ansible CI, if ironic inspector starts up before ironic
API is properly up, we see the following error:

The PXE filter DnsmasqFilter, state=initialized encountered an
exception: StrictVersion instance has no attribute 'version'; resetting
the filter: AttributeError: StrictVersion instance has no attribute
'version'

Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/756342/

The usual cause of this error is when StrictVersion is initialised with
a version of None. This suggests to me that max_ver is None.

This leads to an exception being raised that circumvents the client's
retry mechanisms.

In the particular case of kolla-ansible CI, Ironic API is behind a load
balancer, and all backends are down resulting in a 503. The lack of a
retry caused ironic inspector to fail on startup.

This patch catches the case where we get a 4xx or 5xx return code when
checking the version, and raises an error that works with the client's
retry mechanisms.

Change-Id: Ib62ca3ee4626084e5e9b90e93e4fa97938023457
Story: 2006393
Task: 36266
(cherry picked from commit 0e9bf337f1f6aa41f67df2966dacf9e8e897b7da)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix AttributeError in negotiate_version

Seen in kolla-ansible CI, if ironic inspector starts up before ironic
API is properly up, we see the following error:

The PXE filter DnsmasqFilter, state=initialized encountered an
exception: StrictVersion instance has no attribute 'version'; resetting
the filter: AttributeError: StrictVersion instance has no attribute
'version'

Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/756342/

The usual cause of this error is when StrictVersion is initialised with
a version of None. This suggests to me that max_ver is None.

This leads to an exception being raised that circumvents the client's
retry mechanisms.

In the particular case of kolla-ansible CI, Ironic API is behind a load
balancer, and all backends are down resulting in a 503. The lack of a
retry caused ironic inspector to fail on startup.

This patch catches the case where we get a 4xx or 5xx return code when
checking the version, and raises an error that works with the client's
retry mechanisms.

Change-Id: Ib62ca3ee4626084e5e9b90e93e4fa97938023457
Story: 2006393
Task: 36266
(cherry picked from commit 0e9bf337f1f6aa41f67df2966dacf9e8e897b7da)

[{'created': '2019-12-04 11:26:01.000000000', 'message': "Fix AttributeError in negotiate_version

Seen in kolla-ansible CI, if ironic inspector starts up before ironic
API is properly up, we see the following error:

The PXE filter DnsmasqFilter, state=initialized encountered an
exception: StrictVersion instance has no attribute 'version'; resetting
the filter: AttributeError: StrictVersion instance has no attribute
'version'

Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/756342/

The usual cause of this error is when StrictVersion is initialised with
a version of None. This suggests to me that max_ver is None.

This leads to an exception being raised that circumvents the client's
retry mechanisms.

In the particular case of kolla-ansible CI, Ironic API is behind a load
balancer, and all backends are down resulting in a 503. The lack of a
retry caused ironic inspector to fail on startup.

This patch catches the case where we get a 4xx or 5xx return code when
checking the version, and raises an error that works with the client's
retry mechanisms.

Change-Id: Ib62ca3ee4626084e5e9b90e93e4fa97938023457
Story: 2006393
Task: 36266
(cherry picked from commit 0e9bf337f1f6aa41f67df2966dacf9e8e897b7da)
"}]
commit_message:
Fix AttributeError in negotiate_version

Seen in kolla-ansible CI, if ironic inspector starts up before ironic
API is properly up, we see the following error:

The PXE filter DnsmasqFilter, state=initialized encountered an
exception: StrictVersion instance has no attribute 'version'; resetting
the filter: AttributeError: StrictVersion instance has no attribute
'version'

Example: http://paste.openstack.org/show/756342/

The usual cause of this error is when StrictVersion is initialised with
a version of None. This suggests to me that max_ver is None.

This leads to an exception being raised that circumvents the client's
retry mechanisms.

In the particular case of kolla-ansible CI, Ironic API is behind a load
balancer, and all backends are down resulting in a 503. The lack of a
retry caused ironic inspector to fail on startup.

This patch catches the case where we get a 4xx or 5xx return code when
checking the version, and raises an error that works with the client's
retry mechanisms.

Change-Id: Ib62ca3ee4626084e5e9b90e93e4fa97938023457
Story: 2006393
Task: 36266
(cherry picked from commit 0e9bf337f1f6aa41f67df2966dacf9e8e897b7da)

commit_message:
Review deploy guide MAAS page

This is the second of an intended comprehensive series
of reviews for the deploy guide.

The idea is to pare down the amount of pure MAAS
documentation and defer mostly to upstream for details.
This will provide relief in terms of maintaining this
documentation and make this page more clear and
streamlined.

Closes-Bug: #1787192

Change-Id: I217e06f8f40f024825ee4506c29f828d45d37f73

subject: Cap sphinx for py2 to match global requirements
messages:
[{'account_id': 30384, 'date': '2019-05-16 07:40:49.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-05-16 12:10:03.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

This is a good idea, but I think it would be better to adjust tox.ini to use upper-constraints for the docs and releasenotes venvs.  Then we can rely on u-c to set these properly for each py version [0] (that's the requirements team's job).

[0] https://opendev.org/openstack/requirements/src/branch/master/upper-constraints.txt#L439-L443"}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-05-17 12:13:47.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

@zhangboye: sorry I missed you on IRC.

What you said in IRC is exactly what I'm suggesting, that is, to change the docs (and api-ref) testenvs in tox.ini so that their 'deps' line is:

  deps = 
      -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt}
      -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt

This will use the upper constraints currently defined by the requirements team, but will only actually include the items mentioned in doc/requirements.txt -- this will save us from having to keep track of which version of Sphinx is best for each version of python, that will be done by the requirements team, who take into account how all openstack projects are affected.  (So they have more data to make a decision than we do locally on the Glance team.)"}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-05-20 06:24:04.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

> @zhangboye: sorry I missed you on IRC.
 > 
 > What you said in IRC is exactly what I'm suggesting, that is, to
 > change the docs (and api-ref) testenvs in tox.ini so that their
 > 'deps' line is:
 > 
 > deps =
 > -c{env:UPPER_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://git.openstack.org/cgit/openstack/requirements/plain/upper-constraints.txt}
 > -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt
 > 
 > This will use the upper constraints currently defined by the
 > requirements team, but will only actually include the items
 > mentioned in doc/requirements.txt -- this will save us from having
 > to keep track of which version of Sphinx is best for each version
 > of python, that will be done by the requirements team, who take
 > into account how all openstack projects are affected.  (So they
 > have more data to make a decision than we do locally on the Glance
 > team.)

Brian Thanks for your replay. Yeah, that change need to be consideration."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:53:08.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

But we do need this change as it is, or requirements-check is going to fail. As far as I know this is the correct solution.'}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-12-03 10:53:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 11904, 'date': '2019-12-03 15:30:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2

This change is needed so the requirements match. The py2 line can actually be dropped in master now, but that can be done as a future cleanup.

I think tox changes can actually be done in a different patch too.'}, {'account_id': 5314, 'date': '2019-12-03 16:58:31.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

I'll trust Sean and Luigi in this.  Dropping my objection."}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:16:22.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

I'm all for doing this if we keep the py27 jobs around but if we remove the tags and jobs we should not put any py27 specifics into the requirements either."}, {'account_id': 10459, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:26:52.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 1:

requirements are still needed until all jobs which deploy glance are migrated. That's the curse of being an well used service.

It will be a matter of weeks, but right now we need it."}, {'account_id': 26458, 'date': '2019-12-04 12:45:01.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1

lgtm'}, {'account_id': 5202, 'date': '2019-12-09 16:03:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]

subject: Fallback to default network_driver value if octavia not present
messages: [{'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-28 10:56:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 24791, 'date': '2019-11-29 08:02:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:\n\nrecheck'}, {'account_id': 21798, 'date': '2019-12-03 08:55:27.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 6773, 'date': '2019-12-09 13:44:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-28 10:56:45.000000000', 'message': "Fallback to default network_driver value if octavia not present

In OVN Octavia driver we don't fallback to default network_driver
configuration option value in case of missing octavia module.

We wouldn't add this module to requirements, so better is to
fallback. This will prevent functional test failures.

Change-Id: Ic4c8e81b0d1ab7491bc317c02464bd6853c109fa
Closes-Bug: 1853810
(cherry picked from commit 5804e2bb0d03b0a7eeb5705d6bd5983c056cded0)
"}]
commit_message:
Fallback to default network_driver value if octavia not present

In OVN Octavia driver we don't fallback to default network_driver
configuration option value in case of missing octavia module.

We wouldn't add this module to requirements, so better is to
fallback. This will prevent functional test failures.

Change-Id: Ic4c8e81b0d1ab7491bc317c02464bd6853c109fa
Closes-Bug: 1853810
(cherry picked from commit 5804e2bb0d03b0a7eeb5705d6bd5983c056cded0)

Move utils to the directory above to prepare for v2 api

Move utils from heat/api/openstack/v1/util.py to
heat/api/openstack/util.py for preparing v2 api.

Blueprint: v2-api

commit_message:
Replace ostempest job with plain tripleo standalone

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest was added while porting
tripleo ci jobs to os_tempest and now the porting is done.

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest and
tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone are the same job, It replaces the
existing os_tempest job to plain tripleo standalone job to keep
consistency at all places.

Change-Id: I4e9d5b93be36c9c0cf1b0f6eaec3951130635cd8
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ib14130e9e17a8ba636ce4d91e5d8b60599d16a71
"}, {'created': '2019-12-08 13:41:55.000000000', 'message': "Faster deletion of old vertices

Don't use amqp for consistency to processor msgs - it's the same process
Amqp was used due to historic reasons, when processor and consistency
 were on different processes.
Here consistency will call the processor directly.

Also, is_newer_vertex does not need to parse the date,
the used format can be compared without parsing.

Change-Id: Ib14130e9e17a8ba636ce4d91e5d8b60599d16a71
"}]
commit_message:
Faster deletion of old vertices

Don't use amqp for consistency to processor msgs - it's the same process
Amqp was used due to historic reasons, when processor and consistency
 were on different processes.
Here consistency will call the processor directly.

Also, is_newer_vertex does not need to parse the date,
the used format can be compared without parsing.

Change-Id: Ib14130e9e17a8ba636ce4d91e5d8b60599d16a71

Thank you for your first contribution to OpenStack.

Your patch will now be tested automatically by OpenStack testing frameworks
and once the automatic tests pass, it will be reviewed by other friendly
developers. They will give you feedback and may require you to refine it.

People seldom get their patch approved on the first try, so don't be
concerned if requested to make corrections. Feel free to modify your patch
and resubmit a new change-set.

Patches usually take 3 to 7 days to be reviewed so be patient and be
available on IRC to ask and answer questions about your work. Also it
takes generally at least a couple of weeks for cores to get around to
reviewing code. The more you participate in the community the more
rewarding it is for you. You may also notice that the more you get to know
people and get to be known, the faster your patches will be reviewed and
eventually approved. Get to know others and become known by doing code
reviews: anybody can do it, and it's a great way to learn the code base.

Thanks again for supporting OpenStack, we look forward to working with you.

IRC: https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/IRC
Workflow: https://docs.openstack.org/infra/manual/developers.html

commit_message:

commit_message:
[WIP] Add minified output callback plugin

This change adds a minified output callback plugin that ansible,
via ansible-runner, will use to simplify the output we see in
stdout when running ansible playbooks. This will create a much
better user experience when running playbooks while not impacting
the verbosity of standard ansible logging.

Change-Id: I1f8d9fa4357692c94dae7c63dbce1e63ed5df0b7
Signed-off-by: Kevin Carter <kecarter@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Replace ostempest job with plain tripleo standalone

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest was added while porting
tripleo ci jobs to os_tempest and now the porting is done.

tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone-os-tempest and
tripleo-ci-centos-7-standalone are the same job, It replaces the
existing os_tempest job to plain tripleo standalone job to keep
consistency at all places.

Change-Id: I98d7a44fec4b3b4ba1cf431ac01159da0418f54d
Signed-off-by: Chandan Kumar (raukadah) <chkumar@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Re-arrange status threads to use plugin worker mechanism

This lets us use separate processes for the agent and port
workers. We currently have a large deployment getting
behind on alive updates, due to starvation of processing from
etcd into rabbit.

- First change, split the alive and port status threads into two.
- Second, launch those threads using the neutron plugin get_workers
  mechanism, so we can fork separate processes.
- Third, there's a bug in the etcd watcher registered path parsing,
  which prioritizes wildcard nodes ahead of static nodes, so a
  watched path of "/foo/bar" will *never* be seen if a path of
  "/foo/<host>/blah" exists.
- Fourth, put in an explicit ignore for events we know are there,
  but are not interested in, so the not handled stuff becomes
  a signal of an actual problem.

Change-Id: I9416edc518b99fc006d39dbe8f4558cf88073224

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-09 11:13:33.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone bootstrap error message display

In some situations, Keystone bootstrap can fail, and then unhelpfully
fails displaying the error message output by the 'keystone-manage
bootstrap' command. This appears to be due to unprintable control
characters in the error message which prevent the output of the script
from being valid JSON.

This change fixes the issue by piping the output through 'cat -v', which
replaces unprintable characters with control codes.

Change-Id: I82444bc2272311023cc9e92c5a298d1c4c87483b
Closes-Bug: #1855701
"}, {'created': '2019-12-09 11:14:40.000000000', 'message': "Fix keystone bootstrap error message display

This change fixes the issue by piping the output through 'cat -v', which
replaces unprintable characters with control codes.

Change-Id: I82444bc2272311023cc9e92c5a298d1c4c87483b
Closes-Bug: #1855701
"}]
commit_message:
Fix keystone bootstrap error message display

In some situations, Keystone bootstrap can fail, and then unhelpfully
fails displaying the error message output by the 'keystone-manage
bootstrap' command. This appears to be due to unprintable control
characters in the error message which prevent the output of the script
from being valid JSON.

This change fixes the issue by piping the output through 'cat -v', which
replaces unprintable characters with control codes.

Change-Id: I82444bc2272311023cc9e92c5a298d1c4c87483b
Closes-Bug: #1855701

commit_message:
Make the binding:profile handling consistent in NeutronFixture

For an unbound port real neutron return {} as binding:profile. In the
NeutronFixture the binding:profile key was missing in the predefined
ports. This made the tests asserting the binding:profile inconsistent.

This patch removes the inconsistency by make NeutronFixture behave like
real neutron.

Change-Id: I5a41dbd5c2d28b28bd8e464b6aec3b28ca3b1163
blueprint: support-move-ops-with-qos-ports-ussuri

commit_message:
sensu-client: use docker.io on Debian/Ubuntu

There is no need to use external Docker repo for an image which just
needs Docker client.

Change-Id: I61387287eb3d144ba1686d95b38f95c8292f5b0d

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-08-23 08:09:37.000000000', 'message': "AgularJS pages display dates using Horizon's Settings Timezone

Horizon's AngularJS pages (for example Images and Keypairs)
display dates using browser's timezone now. This change makes
AngularJS pages use Horizon's Settings Timezone instead of
browser's timezone and if Timezone is not set under Settings,
AngularJS pages will display dates in 'UTC' timezone.

Change-Id: Ibbed19600bfe6b13c43b9f09fa484cb78524b0d6
Closes-Bug: 1832768

commit_message:
AgularJS pages display dates using Horizon's Settings Timezone

Horizon's AngularJS pages (for example Images and Keypairs)
display dates using browser's timezone now. This change makes
AngularJS pages use Horizon's Settings Timezone instead of
browser's timezone and if Timezone is not set under Settings,
AngularJS pages will display dates in 'UTC' timezone.

Closes-Bug: 1832768
Change-Id: Ibbed19600bfe6b13c43b9f09fa484cb78524b0d6

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-11-29 16:36:43.000000000', 'message': 'PowerMax Driver - PowerMax Formatted Vols Fix

PowerMax OS (uCode 5978) arrays support adding volumes to a Metro
RDF group without the need for formatting the volume in advance.
This bug fix addresses a bug in the code where PowerMax volumes
are formatted regardless of support.

Change-Id: Ib840d885c8e3d4d13c9d4bc3c88ef8e5d8477788
Closes-Bug: #1829876
(cherry picked from commit e2f52da0d37f77e7a7d619ad1b6c6e098971dac1)
'}]
commit_message:
PowerMax Driver - PowerMax Formatted Vols Fix

PowerMax OS (uCode 5978) arrays support adding volumes to a Metro
RDF group without the need for formatting the volume in advance.
This bug fix addresses a bug in the code where PowerMax volumes
are formatted regardless of support.

Change-Id: Ib840d885c8e3d4d13c9d4bc3c88ef8e5d8477788
Closes-Bug: #1829876
(cherry picked from commit e2f52da0d37f77e7a7d619ad1b6c6e098971dac1)

commit_message:
NEC driver: replace deprecated xml library

Currently, NEC driver uses 'defusedxml.lxml' for parsing xml.
But it is no longer supported and will be removed in a future release.

This patch replaces the deprecated xml library into
'defusedxml.ElementTree'.

This patch also adds test data for xml parsing.

Change-Id: I09a08b45b25291882ee8d9037f7b3e43c307a6cf
Closes-Bug: #1829010
(cherry picked from commit 357379b0a8ce5227713545ac8f2ce7edf026433c)

commit_message:
Convert Pyroute2 byte results to strings

Pyroute2 can return information structures with values as bytes
instead of strings. In order to unify the output, those byte
parameters will be converted to string. This is needed in case of
having dictionaries with keys as bytes instead of strings.

Change-Id: Ic665b2c5e28d06e21190f06d9f3f8e8f8c3c792d
Closes-Bug: #1846360
(cherry picked from commit 592b44629905d68b39ec92604b882627f4844908)

commit_message:
Fix Train release note prelude

An incomplete sentence from a driver change somehow was merged for
Train, making this the overall message we give for the Train release.
This drops that message directly from the train branch since it only
needs to be changed there and we don't want it to accidentally be picked
up again in Ussuri.

Also fixed some minor formatting while I was touching the file.

Change-Id: Iab087cdb038da6e7e226eb7a7a0d44408982d02d
Signed-off-by: Sean McGinnis <sean.mcginnis@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Fix tenant floating_ip_allocation call in neutron rest api.

The call to allocate a new floating IP was incorrecting calling
tenant_floating_ip_allocate, this is used by neutron-lbaas-dashboard.

Change-Id: Ia4d1367ccd309a074a0ea84a555d7de6c07971a6
Closes-bug: #1831954
(cherry picked from commit 92d832028df65cb95030b2a585764a62dc1c0b75)

Please check the detail log before "recheck".
The failure of dsvm-tempest-plugin job will be fixed by https://review.opendev.org/697227.

BTW, I wonder who is taking care of stable/queens. Previously Red Hat and Mirantis folks showed interests for ocata and pike, but I am not sure they are still interested in them. As the horizon PTL, these branches including stable/queens are in the extended maintenance phase, so they are not the area the upstream team is responsible for.'}, {'account_id': 8648, 'date': '2019-12-04 09:26:57.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6914, 'date': '2019-12-04 13:50:11.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

commit_message:
Make minion job voting

We broke the minion job 8 days after we added it. It's green with the
dependent patch. Let's add it to the undercloud/multinode jobs so we
don't break it again.

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/697321/
Change-Id: Idb806253e35ebf8bec764232bd3bdbfa5ce44d90

messages:
[{'account_id': 28278, 'date': '2018-07-12 06:21:43.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 1.'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2018-09-07 12:46:50.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

recheck'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2019-10-03 19:46:55.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-11-29 09:50:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

Sorry for late review, but now we are in Ussuri and py27 can be dropped totally, and py37 is the target.

Do you have time to work on this?'}, {'account_id': 12021, 'date': '2019-11-29 15:31:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: -Code-Review

good point Lajos!

please update to use py37'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-05 05:24:17.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

696952 already updates the default env list in tox.ini,
so this patch is no longer needed.

Note that the default env list just defines what envs are executed
when no env is specified, so it is enough if it covers popular envs
and there is no need to cover all envs.
I think py37 only and py36/py37 are both okay.'}, {'account_id': 841, 'date': '2019-12-05 05:24:30.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review-1'}, {'account_id': 8313, 'date': '2019-12-09 12:47:39.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1:

As Akihiro suggested could you please check https://review.opendev.org/696952, that on was merged and solves this isseu with latest py3x version as well (with py37).
I think this patch is not needed now.'}]

[{'created': '2018-07-12 06:21:43.000000000', 'message': "Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: Id5eb24b0df624ac1461a327ae11d818f80c2bbc4
"}]
commit_message:
Add py36 testenv

Python 3.6 is installed by default in Ubuntu 18.04 LTS.
Therefore, according to Transition Plan [1],
it'll be handy to have py36 testenv.

For more details, please check Python2 Deprecation Timeline [2]
and Python3-first Goal - Completion Criteria [3].

[1] https://wiki.ubuntu.com/Python/Python36Transition
[2] https://governance.openstack.org/tc/resolutions/20180529-python2-deprecation-timeline.html
[3] https://review.openstack.org/#/c/575933/8/goals/stein/python3-first.rst@42

Change-Id: Id5eb24b0df624ac1461a327ae11d818f80c2bbc4

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-05 13:15:40.000000000', 'message': 'New role: ensures we don't get any SELinux denial

This new role ensures we don't have any untracked denials in the system.

The file structure for the denials is the same as for validate-tempest:
skip_list:
  - entry: 'the matcher'
    reason: 'why we want to ignore that one'
    LP: link to the LP bug

In fact, this role is using only the "entry" part, but it's always best
to know why we are ignoring an AVC.

The role will try to load vars from two files, first found first loaded:
selinux_skip_RELEASE_on_VERSION.yml
selinux_skip_RELEASE.yml

The "VERSION" is the major version of the distribution.

There are three parameters you can set within this role:
- skip_list_dest, which is the filename for the generated skip list
- filtered_denials_dest, which is the logfile containing untracked AVCs
- validation_selinux_fail, which allows the validation to fail or not

By default, this validation will not fail.

Change-Id: I38b12feaee8db1c14f0677cfdb07e6abc2be94bc
'}, {'created': '2019-12-05 13:18:12.000000000', 'message': 'New role: ensures we don't get any SELinux denial

commit_message:
New role: ensures we don't get any SELinux denial

This new role ensures we don't have any untracked denials in the system.

The file structure for the denials is the same as for validate-tempest:
skip_list:
  - entry: 'the matcher'
    reason: 'why we want to ignore that one'
    LP: link to the LP bug

In fact, this role is using only the "entry" part, but it's always best
to know why we are ignoring an AVC.

The role will try to load vars from two files, first found first loaded:
selinux_skip_RELEASE_on_VERSION.yml
selinux_skip_RELEASE.yml

The "VERSION" is the major version of the distribution.

There are three parameters you can set within this role:
- skip_list_dest, which is the filename for the generated skip list
- filtered_denials_dest, which is the logfile containing untracked AVCs
- validation_selinux_fail, which allows the validation to fail or not

By default, this validation will not fail.

Change-Id: I38b12feaee8db1c14f0677cfdb07e6abc2be94bc

commit_message:
Switch neutron-dynamic-routing job to be non-voting temporaray

This job is now broken due to [1]. Revert for this patch is already
proposed in [2] but as this block all patches in neutron-tempest-plugin
repo, and there are in queue patches which should improve stability of
other neutron scenario jobs, lets not wait until [2] will be merged and
quickly unblock gates now.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/288271/
[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/691710/

Change-Id: I3951fa12a3b2c840ba2a11f22a298e7926aef649
Related-Bug: #1850626

commit_message:
[OVN] Move OVN ACL commands to Neutron tree

Once networking-ovn.common.acl code is in Neutron tree, the ACL
commands can be implemented.

Previous paths in networking-ovn tree:
./networking_ovn/ovsdb/commands.py ->
  ./neutron/plugins/ml2/drivers/ovn/mech_driver/ovsdb/commands.py

Co-Authored-By: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

Change-Id: Ic0cb48887901d16ad0304be6ad55dca1df4fadd0
Partially-Implements: blueprint neutron-ovn-merge

commit_message:
Default to etcd3gw driver for etcd-based coordination

To fix instability and availability issues:

etcd3 is not available in repos for binary kolla images.

etcd3 does not support eventlet-based services [1].

[1] https://review.opendev.org/466098

Change-Id: I430bab735da204fc81696130b17931a89214c876
Closes-bug: #1852086
Closes-bug: #1854932
(cherry picked from commit 58b5acbf65013f468db3fe73349689271a3c287e)

commit_message:
Add command to deploy only containers

Kolla ansible train adds a new command, kolla-ansible deploy-containers,
that will only deploy containers, and skips registration, bootstrapping
and configuration.

This change adds a new 'kayobe overcloud service deploy containers'
command to make use of the new kolla-ansible command.

Change-Id: I999dfe4b1d082bc88148f54b236644abcbd96a5a
Story: 2006951
Task: 37633

us to link to the same release of the documentation for other projects,

commit_message:
Drop deprecated options

eventlet_server has been deprecated in N [1]
member_role_name and admin_endpoint has been used for v2 only
secure_proxy_ssl_header has been removed in P

[1]https://docs.openstack.org/keystone/train/configuration/config-options.html#eventlet-server

Change-Id: I6bf3eaa1cacb34ba67e6afc63a62d2512bff4d53

commit_message:
Update: Ensure parallel execution

In middle of Queens and Rocky release we introduced option to
set parallel execution of minor update on selected role types.
If the environment went through FFWD or was deployed before this
option got backported we need to update the roles_data.

By default we have update_serial either unset at all for OSP13 and OSP14 or
we have it set where Pacemaker enabled nodes, CephOSD nodes and Networkers
have it set to 1. This is mostly defensive precaution and we do allow running
in parallel for CephOSD and Networkers for production systems that did enough
testing on preprod or can take small outage. We should also parallelize it in
CI as we just waste time here.

Change-Id: I4cff09dc6aa9ac944b20a52ae087a8923f55209f

I also added some more clarifications to the proposed changes as well as the API impact section."}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2018-11-19 14:12:57.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 4.'}, {'account_id': 9708, 'date': '2018-11-20 10:37:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

Thanks for the update. Overall the spec looks good. 
Based on the extra information in the spec I can foresee a data model impact. See inline. 

Cheers,
gibi'}, {'account_id': 4690, 'date': '2018-12-06 00:16:44.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

-1 for the lack of blueprint link and the lack of detail in the Work Items section.

I think the overall idea in this spec sounds good, but I'm noting that there's not yet consensus on where the shared library should be located (whether to use openstacksdk, os-brick, or other). We might need to start another ML thread about that on openstack-discuss@ to find consensus with a wider audience. The glance spec is also doesn't look close to consensus/approval yet."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-05-20 14:11:27.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)

I'm strongly opposed to this.

We appear be selling something which promised not to expose unencrypted data internally on OpenStack services. However, we do exactly this except for a small number of volume types (rbd, I think?) which use qemu native encryption. LVM specifically is called out in the spec as an example to be copied, when in fact the opposite is true. When unencrypted, we expose the unencrypted data as a block device on the compute host when exactly the same protection as any other unencrypted disk. And this is without considering the protection afforded to secrets handled by nova after they are obtained by barbican, or how much we can trust barbican if we don't trust nova.

Adding encryption of glance images to this mix gives us no actual security benefits beyond simply setting permissions on the image to restrict its visibility. Consequently all we'd be adding is complexity. There are no security benefits to doing this.

I would like to see us fully defining the threats we are attempting to mitigate. If we decide that disk encryption mitigates those threats, we need to ensure we have implemented it thoroughly before it's worth adding encrypted glance images."}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-05-23 09:36:16.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4:

So quick replies to some of Matt's comments before I go into the spec itself.

 > (1 comment)
 > 
 > I'm strongly opposed to this.
 > 
 > We appear be selling something which promised not to expose
 > unencrypted data internally on OpenStack services. However, we do
 > exactly this except for a small number of volume types (rbd, I
 > think?) which use qemu native encryption. 

You're mixing volumes and ephemeral storage here. Additionally native decryption of LUKS volumes by QEMU is the default now for all _volume_ types (assuming the required versions of Libvirt and QEMU are available).

 > LVM specifically is called out in the spec as an example to be copied,
 > when in fact the opposite is true. When unencrypted, we expose the
 > unencrypted data as a block device on the compute host when exactly 
 > the same protection as any other unencrypted disk. And this is without
 > considering the protection afforded to secrets handled by nova
 > after they are obtained by barbican, or how much we can trust
 > barbican if we don't trust nova.

Right and if anything that needs to be addressed by introducing the same native LUKS decryption support that we have for volumes into the imagebackend for the Libvirt virt driver."}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-05-23 14:53:00.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 4: Code-Review-1

(11 comments)

I'm on board with the data confidentiality at rest use case I just can't understand why we need to encrypt and stream images using GPG etc when formats such as LUKS potentially simplify alot of the complexity outlined here."}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-06-18 13:55:59.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 5.'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:04:35.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 6.'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-06-19 08:15:39.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 7.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-06-24 19:05:55.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 7:

This is nicely described, but pretty high-level. As a Nova maintainer, I'd like to see more detail on which Nova (presumably VM lifecycle) flows are impacted and how.

I would also like to understand the chain of dependencies with other projects. I.e. which pieces are prerequisites of which others?"}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-02 07:35:12.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 8.'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-02 07:37:13.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8:

I added a few more details in the proposed change section.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-02 13:57:29.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

Okay, assuming the deps come together, this seems reasonable and simple and nonintrusive from the Nova side.

We need to do some paperwork, then I'm +2:
- File a blueprint [1]. The blueprint name and spec file basename should match.
- Tag the blueprint in the commit message (e.g. Blueprint: image-encryption) and in the gerrit topic (e.g. bp/image-encryption).
- Link to the blueprint URL at the top of the spec (see the template [2]).

[1] https://blueprints.launchpad.net/nova/+addspec
[2] http://specs.openstack.org/openstack/nova-specs/specs/train/approved/train-template.html"}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-02 21:30:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review+1

(3 comments)

over all i think this is well presented.
i dont normally review the storage side of nova much but is have some
quetions inline regarding lifecycle opertaiton on an instance with an encryped image.

i am still +1 on this change regardless of the limitation on move operations but we shoudl document them so that operators are aware of the implications of using this feature.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-02 21:46:19.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: Code-Review-1

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-02 21:47:36.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 8: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-03 11:09:07.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from 608696 to bp/image-encryption'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-03 11:23:34.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 9.'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-03 12:06:02.000000000', 'content': 'Topic changed from 608696 to bp/image-encryption'}, {'account_id': 10135, 'date': '2019-07-03 13:08:49.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 8:

(6 comments)

Argh, this tab has been open so long that I've ended up reviewing an older PS. Posting anyway as this LGTM and my nits can be ignored."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-03 21:18:54.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 9: Code-Review-1

There were discussions today in IRC [1][2] concluding that more thought needs to be given to the shelve and cross-cell resize operations. TL;DR: we either need to enhance those APIs to allow the admin to request encryption of the snapshots created thereby; or we need to "remember" that the instance came from an encrypted image and do so automatically (in which case where does the key come from?)

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-07-03.log.html#t2019-07-03T11:26:32
[2] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/irclogs/%23openstack-nova/%23openstack-nova.2019-07-03.log.html#t2019-07-03T13:57:12'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-04 12:41:50.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 10.'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-04 12:57:45.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

We changed the encryption part - to use a method we call key-lock. That would be used for shelve, resize and snapshot creation. So we have a symmetry between these behaviors.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-04 13:32:26.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review+1

thanks for updating
im happy with the new version assuming other are too
i think we are in a good position to move forward to the implementation at this point'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-15 22:14:23.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10: Code-Review-1

(12 comments)

Downvote for missing details on conf options.

Other things are mostly questions, the answers to which may prompt other changes.

Thanks!'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-22 11:51:16.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 10:

(3 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-07-23 12:37:02.000000000', 'content': 'Uploaded patch set 11.'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-23 13:19:53.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+2

(2 comments)

Thanks for fleshing out the config opts. I think this is good to go now.'}, {'account_id': 11604, 'date': '2019-07-23 16:03:15.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: Code-Review+1

(2 comments)

i was generally happy with the previous iterations so this still looks good to me.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-07-29 15:24:24.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(5 comments)

I've got a few scheduling and upgrade-related concerns in here which I think should be addressed. It's not clear to me if the compute service changes are generic or specific to each virt driver and if the latter, will this only be implemented by the libvirt driver?

Also wondering about the createBackup API - I'm OK with not supporting this in that API, but we should call it out."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 17:39:12.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11: -Code-Review'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-07-29 22:19:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

SFE requested: http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-July/008096.html'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-08-01 08:54:31.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(4 comments)'}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-01 14:14:58.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(1 comment)'}, {'account_id': 1004, 'date': '2019-08-01 21:54:38.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(5 comments)'}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-08-02 09:16:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

(2 comments)'}, {'account_id': 4393, 'date': '2019-08-05 17:32:57.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(6 comments)

On the subject of a freeze exception for this, I feel like this doesn't really qualify for such a thing based on the current state. There are still quite a few unanswered questions (or at least confusing assertions) in here, and no mention of which virt drivers are going to be supported, or can be supported in the future, etc. I've not reviewed this yet, so maybe that's just my interpretation, but I thought I'd offer it up regardless.

Anyway, threw some first-read comments in here which I think need to be addressed, as well as those from the others which are yet unanswered."}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-08 14:39:15.000000000', 'content': "Abandoned

Agreed in today's Nova meeting to deny spec freeze exception for this [1]. As soon as the U release has a name, we'll add it to nova-specs. At that time, you should restore this and move it to U. (If you want to continue working on it in the interim, you may restore it in the backlog/ directory.)

[1] http://eavesdrop.openstack.org/meetings/nova/2019/nova.2019-08-08-14.01.log.html#l-106"}, {'account_id': 14070, 'date': '2019-08-30 13:52:35.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 11:

The nova-specs repository has been populated for ussuri. You may restore and move this spec if needed.'}, {'account_id': 6873, 'date': '2019-09-09 13:10:23.000000000', 'content': 'Restored

Will be proposed for Ussuri.'}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-07 14:34:09.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11: Code-Review-1

(2 comments)

Lots of issues here which I won't go into now as I plan to speak to you tomorrow. I'm sure there's a way forward with your use case, though."}, {'account_id': 9555, 'date': '2019-11-12 12:32:13.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

Summary of our discussion was:

You aren't going to gain the benefits you're hoping to gain by using a 'streamable' format in practise. Because the hypervisor can't directly consume GPG, you're going to have to decrypt and store the whole thing on the compute host. I would much prefer to see this use encryption which can be directly consumed by the hypervisor, e.g. LUKS.

Given the above constraints, the risk of this feature is significantly increased because we don't yet have support for encryption of ephemeral disks[1], so don't know for sure how that feature would be implemented in practise.

I appreciate that encrypted images are, theoretically at least, a separate problem to ephemeral storage, however IIUC your goal is to get to a place where the user must supply the relevant keys in order to start an instance. In order to get there you're also going to need encrypted ephemeral support. I suggest a much safer option would be to implement that first.

An interim alternative is to rely on encrypted volume support, although presumably even there you've had to implement support for GPG to LUKS conversion in cinder, or the resulting volume isn't encrypted?

[1] discounting LVM, which isn't a model we want to replicate."}, {'account_id': 28271, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:46:36.000000000', 'content': "Patch Set 11:

After talking to Matthew at the Shanghai Summit, we will abandon this spec for.

Matthew already summarized the problem: What we would like to have (somewhen in the future) is a chain of encrypted resources, which can be transferred into each other.

With adding the image encryption, openstack would have this chain from encrypted image, encrypted volume and encrypted volume-backed server for the volume side. In nova currently the encrypted ephemeral storage is still missing, therefore we don't have such a chain of encrypted resources in nova. We wanted to already make nova capable of using encrypted images, but as it seems it might be a better idea to wait until there is an ephemeral storage encryption in nova.

Thank you for the discussions at several points. We might come back on this spec in the future. In the mean time, we will provide image encryption in glance and cinder."}, {'account_id': 27665, 'date': '2019-12-09 09:53:20.000000000', 'content': 'Abandoned

Abandoning this spec for now as a result of the discussions, mainly due to the missing ephemeral storage encryption support needed for a coherent security model concerning image encryption in Nova.'}]

commit_message:
Spec for the Nova part of Image Encryption

We want to propose Image Encryption for Openstack, which would affect Nova,
but also Cinder and Glance. This spec contains the details of the Nova part
for the Image Encryption. The transformations from encrypted images to
ephemeral storage as well as creating encrypted images from existing servers
are discussed.

blueprint image-encryption

Change-Id: Ib3519f97ca1c6573462b2216433394e86c013e2a
Co-Authored-By: Josephine Seifert <josephine.seifert@secustack.com>

commit_message:
Add cycle-trailing deadline to release schedule

The deadline for projects following the cycle-trailing release
model is 3 months after the coordinated release.  Add a note
to the Ussuri schedule at R-18 (12 weeks after the Train release).

Change-Id: If1ac66fd6b0e52d86d762bf05674e310bd3d7934

commit_message:
Add nginx_ingress_controller_chart_tag

Additioanlly, bumping up the Chart version to 1.24.7 without which the
ingress controller fails to deploy on 1.16.x.

Additionally, bump up nginx_ingress_controller_tag version to 0.26.1.
This is to ensure that we are running an up to date nginx ingress
controller with fixes for known CVEs.

Story: 2006853
Task: 37444

Change-Id: Ibf045a06d19b02095e19d9a21d14a91a39a3751c
(cherry picked from commit 7d6e344f1a585a288d0873c981f2102e0f3084fa)

revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-06 11:39:34.000000000', 'message': 'test USE_PYTHON3=False

Change-Id: I71c6a20f32650bc58953d237da9aa80bef4d1f60
'}, {'created': '2019-12-07 03:52:51.000000000', 'message': 'Specify USE_PYTHON3=False explicitly

Currently our devstack jobs are with python2 because
they all are on centos-7, where python3 is not ready.
They recently started failing with "python3.5 not found" for
some reasons. (I haven't investigated why.)
Specify USE_PYTHON3=False as a workaround.

Closes-Bug: #1855512
Change-Id: I71c6a20f32650bc58953d237da9aa80bef4d1f60
'}]
commit_message:
Specify USE_PYTHON3=False explicitly

Currently our devstack jobs are with python2 because
they all are on centos-7, where python3 is not ready.
They recently started failing with "python3.5 not found" for
some reasons. (I haven't investigated why.)
Specify USE_PYTHON3=False as a workaround.

Closes-Bug: #1855512
Change-Id: I71c6a20f32650bc58953d237da9aa80bef4d1f60

messages: [{'account_id': 28022, 'date': '2019-12-06 11:50:34.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Cherry Picked from branch master.'}, {'account_id': 20498, 'date': '2019-12-07 17:17:40.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2'}, {'account_id': 27336, 'date': '2019-12-08 15:09:25.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+1'}, {'account_id': 6484, 'date': '2019-12-09 07:55:29.000000000', 'content': 'Patch Set 1: Code-Review+2 Workflow+1'}]
revisions:
[{'created': '2019-12-06 11:50:34.000000000', 'message': '[k8s] Fix rolling upgrade with podman

There are some small regression issues introduced by the podman
support patch. And another issue is since k8s v1.16, the daemonsets
has been moved app/v1 from extensions[1], so we need to update the
system:node-drainer ClusterRole so that kubectl can be called on
worker node to trigger the drain process. Both issues are fixed
in this patch.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/notes/#deprecations-and-removals

Task: 37642
Story: 2005201

Change-Id: I87ed49fd1e9cd513ae54f6758717379adafae3a4
(cherry picked from commit cab9492dffb71c51a5212b3ef40f537550bebcbd)
'}]
commit_message:
[k8s] Fix rolling upgrade with podman

There are some small regression issues introduced by the podman
support patch. And another issue is since k8s v1.16, the daemonsets
has been moved app/v1 from extensions[1], so we need to update the
system:node-drainer ClusterRole so that kubectl can be called on
worker node to trigger the drain process. Both issues are fixed
in this patch.

[1] https://kubernetes.io/docs/setup/release/notes/#deprecations-and-removals

Task: 37642
Story: 2005201

Change-Id: I87ed49fd1e9cd513ae54f6758717379adafae3a4
(cherry picked from commit cab9492dffb71c51a5212b3ef40f537550bebcbd)

[{'created': '2019-11-15 12:35:59.000000000', 'message': 'deploy-steps-tasks/containers: set concurrency to 2

After some testing, it seems like podman run/exec/create commands can be
run at the same time and decrease the deployment time when 2 commands
(maximum) at the same time are run.

Example of benchmark done for an Undercloud deployment in my local environment:
- With Paunch enabled: 26 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 1: 32 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 2: 29 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 3: 33 min

(Above 4, results are worse).

commit_message:
deploy-steps-tasks/containers: set concurrency to 2

After some testing, it seems like podman run/exec/create commands can be
run at the same time and decrease the deployment time when 2 commands
(maximum) at the same time are run.

Example of benchmark done for an Undercloud deployment in my local environment:
- With Paunch enabled: 26 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 1: 32 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 2: 29 min
- With Paunch disabled and concurrency set to 3: 33 min

(Above 4, results are worse).

Change-Id: Ie7fc754046611a339c743141fe28f801f4e4b331

commit_message:
Enlarge tags support

Workflow and task executions will inherit tags from
definition. Executions filtering by tag is included.

Change-Id: Id5d615b829901258af2be7ca99178ad92b60d1fb
Closes-Bug: #1853457
Signed-off-by: Oleg Ovcharuk <vgvoleg@gmail.com>

commit_message:
Add common navbar and display MOTD on all pages

Now that we have a page for etherpads, navigation between the various
page is a bit awkward. This change introduces a common navbar across
all pages, and makes sure the MOTD displays on all of them.

This makes some of the links redundant, so we remove them.

Change-Id: I57d02c505ced355d53bc79e0d8240ea63737eae3

commit_message:
No more networking-ovn in Ussuri

Remove the Ussuri deliverable file for networking-ovn so that we do not
expect releases for networking-ovn, since it will be merged back into
Neutron during this cycle.

Change-Id: I8151c1dbf6ca7b76f9c1dc665205480f5746590b

commit_message:
[ussuri][goal] Drop python 2.7 support and testing

OpenStack is dropping the py2.7 support in ussuri cycle.

ceilometer is ready with python 3 and ok to drop the
python 2.7 support.

Complete discussion & schedule can be found in
- http://lists.openstack.org/pipermail/openstack-discuss/2019-October/010142.html
- https://etherpad.openstack.org/p/drop-python2-support

Ussuri Communtiy-wide goal:
https://governance.openstack.org/tc/goals/selected/ussuri/drop-py27.html

Depends-On: https://review.opendev.org/#/c/693631/

Change-Id: Ie8523712ea2ebe828fe01a649b6add90e813608b

commit_message:
Imported Translations from Zanata

For more information about this automatic import see:
https://docs.openstack.org/i18n/latest/reviewing-translation-import.html

This change contained many RST errors, let's import strings that are
sane to reduce the delta. translate.openstack.org was updated for issues
found so far.

Change-Id: If2ce6000830be2cf6d0e61f5130274253e674488

commit_message:
Fix some issues with replicate with mysql

This patch will fix following issues:

- Existed logs xbstream
- '@@GLOBAL.GTID_PURGED can only be set when @@GLOBAL.GTID_EXECUTED is empty.

Change-Id: I0968cd794801285fa6effd5da2770e1270e3cfb2
Story: #2006656
Task: #36903

commit_message:
Revert "Add retries when loading keystone data and fetching endpoints"

Now that we can use connect_retries with keystone session[1]
for retries, we should revert this change.

This reverts commit 6fb8ac250ae27810516b89f273923d6b786606b5.

[1] https://review.opendev.org/676664

Change-Id: I70ad41b12095eede617fd8dc454b5761697ea50a

commit_message:
Adds --before archive parameter to cron job

Adds --before to the archive command based on age parameter provided.
If added, it will run with:
--before `date --date='today - #{params[:age]} days' +\\%F`

Change-Id: I3af194696b87f6e17e9576c48f69ec7dde2640fd

commit_message:
Include project_id in Prometheus publisher

It's quite useful to have a project ID included in Prometheus data so that one
can filter data based on projects. Currently it only includes the resource_id
which can be difficult to track for a project.

Change-Id: Ied85839d089a019c0511cb5600d6bdaa811d5d1a

[{'created': '2019-11-25 09:38:45.000000000', 'message': 'Support multiple member_of query parameter

The ``openstack allocation candidate list`` and the ``openstack
allocation candidate list`` command now supports ``--member-of``
option, which accepts a list of comma-separated UUIDs of the
resource provider aggregates. If this is specified, the returned
resource providers must be associated with at least one of the
aggregates identified by uuid. This option can be repeated to
add(restrict) the condition with ``--os-placement-api-version 1.24``
or greater.

This deprecates the ``--aggregate-uuid`` option because it is
difficult to keep using this option to support multiple ``member_of``
feature added in microversion 1.24.

commit_message:
Support multiple member_of query parameter

The ``openstack allocation candidate list`` and the ``openstack
allocation candidate list`` command now supports ``--member-of``
option, which accepts a list of comma-separated UUIDs of the
resource provider aggregates. If this is specified, the returned
resource providers must be associated with at least one of the
aggregates identified by uuid. This option can be repeated to
add(restrict) the condition with ``--os-placement-api-version 1.24``
or greater.

This deprecates the ``--aggregate-uuid`` option because it is
difficult to keep using this option to support multiple ``member_of``
feature added in microversion 1.24.

Change-Id: I22eee5b7d2d7501cb3fb69bc5b30068031dc808e
Story: #2006940
Task: #37613

We need to change this everywhere so that we can
